item.name: Estoril 1942: A Game of Spies
item.comment:
a great hidden roles game with tons of replay value. Teams of spies recruit, subvert or eliminate the competition. Nicely fits into an hour and plenty of strategy. The iconography is clear and concise and thematic :)
One of the best new games this year!

item.name: Euchre
item.comment: Classic trick game with short hand. A great way to spend time with anyone.

item.name: Euphoria: Build a Better Dystopia
item.comment:
I'm getting it for the image of the people in the hamster wheels!
Shipping 12/13
item.wishlistcomment: Love the hamster wheels...

item.name: Evolution: The Origin of Species
item.comment: Potentially neat game, but what your really waiting for is food scarcity when you have initiative. Given that narrow strategy you are building a Rube Goldberg creature that manages to survive by being in the right place in the turn order. Better than Dominant Species by virtue of a short playing time.

item.name: Exodus: Proxima Centauri
item.comment: Does this compare to either TI3 or Eclipse? I hope I get to find out.

item.name: Exodus: Proxima Centauri
item.comment: Hoping the 2nd edition is worth acquiring...
item.wishlistcomment: New edition...worth it?

item.name: Expedition: Northwest Passage
item.comment: Cool looking, but is it fun?
item.wishlistcomment: A must play this year.

item.name: Extra! Extra!
item.comment: It's worker placement with set collection and a puzzle board as a newspaper layout. There's decent use of theme throughout and plenty of variability in the use and usefulness of worker spaces, plays best with at least 4 or more. With fewer players it's a short boring race. I like the use of money to protect spaces. I wish the board was in one piece.

item.name: Fading Glory
item.comment:
Nicely done low complexity game...after several plays I love the Nap20 system! In this deluxe production there are four very replayable battles towards the end of the era. The rules are easy to learn and VPG supports fans with living rules. Sadly this might be the pinnacle component-wise, but there are many titles to explore, one hour at a time.
Highly worth owning!

item.name: Fairy Tale
item.comment: a great drafting game, very quick and entertaining.

item.name: Fantastiqa: Enchanted Edition
item.comment:
Deck building mixed with board game movement and unique VP scoring (quests). Classic Fantasy/Folklore themes and art are integrated as related mechanics (billy goat defeats troll).
played a prototype. Based solely on that play it is not a children's games nor a game for adults I would enjoy, it seems unlikely that I'll ever get a chance to play the finished version.

item.name: A Few Acres of Snow
item.comment:
Is it a wargame? WHO CARES! This game surpasses it's deck building roots by giving you a reason to develop a strategy and interact fully with your opponent.
The fact that it is a two-player just personalizes the tension as you try to do more than score points.
Wallace scores another 10! (umm, I mean "9" due to my own rating paradigm) ;)

item.name: Field of Glory
item.comment: Better than most historical rulesets, but still fails to make it fun. Too many steps, layers and details, "oh my!"

item.name: Field of Glory: The Card Game
item.comment:
Must own regardless
Great little fencing match across a battle line with ancient soldier units.
item.wishlistcomment: Waiting to buy...impatiently

item.name: Filthy Rich
item.comment:
it has a clever design and plays well. I just never seem to play it...
In 2006 I purged my games and gave this away.

item.name: Fire & Axe: A Viking Saga
item.comment:
Yet one more I should have played by now...
Having finally played it I was more than a little unprepared for such a screwage intensive game. It's more of an old school "take that" game than I thought. Regardless it was fun even if I played it badly.
I need to try it again, but next time I'll have a dagger in my boot, a sword in my lap, and an axe slung across my back...then I'll be ready to set sail!

item.name: Fire in the Lake
item.comment: Having played other coin games, this on requires study as the American player is decidedly asymmetrical from the other combatants. Worth many plays but I fear I'll never really get this one. Great and fun event cards!

item.name: Fireball Island
item.comment: Lovely game to look at and great fun to start, the rules grind into nonsense, but the laughter trumps the tedium. Everyone should try this once.

item.name: First to Fight
item.comment: Follow the exploits of Polish partisans in WWII
item.wishlistcomment: I find the most interesting designs and the compelling themes have come from Poland for many years. I think this one is another winner.

item.name: First Train to Nuremberg
item.comment: visual redux, 2 maps and play variants. Thank you to everyone that saw this through; I could not enjoy the eyesore of the original release. Now this is a Wallace Classic!

item.name: Fist of Dragonstones
item.comment: this holds up better when playing with younger kids, but doesn't get much attention from adults. the game is solid enough, but very lite. A decent gateway game.

item.name: Five Points: Gangs of New York
item.comment:
Speculating...picked it up and getting it to the table soon, more to report after plays
Initial play lack luster area control, not bad, but utterly themeless.
item.wishlistcomment: ok...I am sitting on my hands...now can you please tell me something about this game?

item.name: Five Tribes: The Djinns of Naqala
item.comment: Interesting use of mancala with non-linear movement options.

item.name: Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game
item.comment: The only thing worse that WH40K is someone developing another game rooted in WH40K. It's an exercise in making terrain, painting figures, setting up the board, rolling dice and hiding. bored to tears = Flames of War.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment:
solid and nightmarish! the chaos is fun and the sense of immediate peril forces selfless acts of reckless heroism. not at all like being a real fireman, but as close as I'm likely to come.
Watching a "victim" die when they are in front of you is painful

item.name: Fleet
item.comment: Received in a trade, given away to a better home

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment:
mensa approved or not this game is fun once in a while, but lacks the type of strategy I enjoy. chaos mgmt. just isn't for me.
This non-game was banished in the purge of '06

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: Quick fun, great little filler

item.name: For The Win
item.comment: Like Hive, which is like Chess, but not Chess or Hive. It's probably better than I am rating it, but I vastly prefer my GIPF collection.

item.name: The foreign King
item.comment: Sort of like el Grande, and not a bad filler game. Seemed kinda simple with a natural rhythm of actions and waiting for your moment to capitalize on the choices made by the other players. In the end I'd rather just play el Grande.

item.name: Formula D
item.comment: Fun but overly long and too much downtime.

item.name: Formula D√©
item.comment: Too many tracks to the point that I don't care which one we play on. It's also too long to be fun, especially with folks that only plan when it's their turn.

item.name: Fortress America
item.comment: I'm generally not a fan of "all against one" games, and I'm not considering playing as America at any point, but I did have fun. The limited units of the invaders is a seriously cool part of the game.

item.name: Founding Fathers
item.comment: Something this history based should have something that actually feels like context, but the mechanics don't seem to model the people that formed the basis for the America we celebrate. The things that pass a legislation are insignificant. What a huge bore...expensive too. Numbingly so.

item.name: Founding Fathers
item.comment:
A fun reworking of Republic of Rome with better sequences of negotiation and changing cast of characters. Additionally, the issues being less abstract and the lack of constant military campaign make for a fun experience.
Recommend for history buffs and RoR fans.

item.name: Frag
item.comment: played it once, boring, bought the expansions and the miniatures, it didn't help. I recently gave these away to save the garbage man the trouble of compacting them

item.name: Frag Deadlands
item.comment: not my cup of tea, annoying mechanic. this was another closet cleaning give-away, fortunately someone who had no idea or a clue was willing to take it for free...for a while I thought I might have to pay them to get this turd away from me.

item.name: Frank Herbert's Dune
item.comment: Seeing how the Dune license was sacrificed on the altar of the Herbert estate's greed, this stands as the ultimate published version of the game. Many lovely print and play versions exist, but I love this copy...'cuz I own it ;)

item.name: Friedrich
item.comment:
I will never play this again.
I find the map to be very busy; for a game with so many abstracted design concepts, the amount of spaces are overkill.
Due to the card/deck mechanism if you are a mediocre card counter you will have to really mess up to lose as Prussia.
The retreat rules can take a non-Prussia player out of the game in one unfortunate combat forcing them to limp for a long time knowing full well a fate card can remove them from play while the are trying to get back in the mix.
I disliked the control sheets intensely as it was beyond irritating having to record information in a boardgame; particularly a wargame/euro hybrid.
After discussing gameplay with the designer and others, I see how this could be played better by a group of players more familiar with game, but I don't enjoy the map or the control sheet.

item.name: Frontiers
item.comment:
After several plays, I lowered my rating from a 8 to a 4. The initial games were entertaining and the stats on the "minis" was a boon to the learning curve of the game.
Where the game fails is in the card play. Because the system relies on d6 mechanics and the cards have very beneficial modifiers, there were only rare occasions where I was actually at risk of failing an action. In the end the entire game falls apart. It would be nice to think that without the cards the game would be still playable, but it is not.
I solved my problem by donating this to a friend's start up gaming club. Maybe it will be fun for them...

item.name: Fuentes de O√±oro 20
item.comment: Stand alone deluxe battle

item.name: Full Thrust
item.comment: open-ended, great physics model, ship design tools, works with any mini's any theme. always exciting!

item.name: Funny Friends
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
hilarious way to conduct an auction...never seen so many people take to excessive behavior so quickly.
I did see that there are many folks who would never choose to play this twice. I had fun.

item.name: Fzzzt!
item.comment:
good light game with lots of strategy emerging after first plays.
It's an ok "mini-deck builder" I sold it off as I don't need another filler game.

item.name: G.E.V.
item.comment: If you thought I have too many copies of OGRE/G.E.V. you would be correct!

item.name: Galaxy Defenders
item.comment:
Lots of stuff, lots of dice, lots of minis, it's a light video game-like RPG-ish experience game.
Basically it's a bit too much of everything that leaves me cold...if this is supposed to be tabletop X-Com, I'll play the computer game, really too much to manage as a boardgame IMO.

item.name: The Gallerist
item.comment: Played prototype

item.name: The Game of Life
item.comment: The version with the rolling hills and clicky spinner was a staple in my house...you almost forgive the roll and move, time wll spent before I played gamer games

item.name: A Game of Thrones (first edition)
item.comment: I will give it one thing, it may not be my favorite, but it sure is better than Friedrich!

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
item.comment:
A 6-player game that is better than the previous edition. The added kicker card in combat reminds me of the die roll in Washington's War for the strategy rating. The House cards are themed really well for each side.
A long game worth the occasional few play, but still not a game I would play regularly.
After additional plays, I don't enjoy the scripted attack patterns and the sense that Greyjoy is far too powerful if the Stark player does not confront early.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game
item.comment: A significantly better representation of the world of the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros. An insane number of expansions are terrifying to some.

item.name: "La Garde recule!"
item.comment: free "postcard" game from Turning Point Simulations, part of the Great Postcard Purge.

item.name: Gearworld: The Borderlands
item.comment:
Dull trading and joyless combat. As a footnote it may have been novel a long time ago, but is significantly eclipsed by Game of Thrones.
No need to ever play this again.

item.name: Genoa
item.comment: Trading euro highly regarded

item.name: German Railways
item.comment: glad to see this treated like a Queen.

item.name: Gettysburg
item.comment: The second tactical level wargame by Martin Wallace. Much easier ruleset than Waterloo. A challenging 2-player for both sides.

item.name: Giganten
item.comment: Looking forward to what FFG is publishing, Giganten is a beautiful game that is getting new life, very hopeful.

item.name: Gin Rummy
item.comment: An enjoyable trick taking game, unless you play with folks who can't agree on the variant to play or change rules mid game...I prefer Tichu and Hearts

item.name: GIPF
item.comment:
based on my inability to think through the game. I make ridicolous errors constantly. Given that I play other games in the seriews very well, my rating is likely to improve once I "get it".
I am in awe of the meta game for this series. all six games and the 3 GIPF sets are a must for any lover of abstracts!

item.name: Glass Road
item.comment:
This might be the Uwe Rosenberg game for me.
Well...my initial impression might be true, if only because the game is so short. You don't really accomplish much unless you focus on a strategy early. I don't suggest ever upgrading your core structures and be sure to accumulate the max sand, glass and brick (9 points). Scoring over 20 seems to be a challenge, but if you do, you probably won the game.
Optimally you want to match 2 of your opponents cards and have several exclusive (double effect) cards plays. If you're lucky to do this twice in the 4 rounds, the advantages are telling.
Glad to have played it, but it replaces nothing in my collection.
item.wishlistcomment: Finally...a Rosenberg game for me?

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: I did not do well my first play...seems I was chasing the wrong stuff constantly. Perhaps we play again soon? On subsequent plays I did better, but it is very easy to fall prey to simplistic goals. It is very important that your scoring items are only based on who has the least of each, not each player.

item.name: Gloom
item.comment: the cards are neat, but the readability suck and the overall gameplay suffers as a result of the printing and color range used.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment:
I see why people are crazy about this game, but I honestly feel this game rewards min max strategy to such a high degree that luck on the initial draws and plays guarantees a win, no need to ever play it again.
However I would play again if a fan asked me to.

item.name: Go
item.comment: Classic game; I am looking for a nice classy version

item.name: Go da Cheese!
item.comment: Run around a wheel of cards hopefully playing them in a beneficial sequence or order to score points by getting cheese or capturing opponents mice and cats. Amusing in large groups, but not the type of game is play often.

item.name: Go Fish
item.comment: Essential card game for learning basic rules and an example of low effort wish fulfillment with dubious rewards.

item.name: God's Playground
item.comment:
waiting for my order to ship, really looking forward to another 3-player!
It's to collaborate against each other!
A great system of steps with a steady ratcheting of tension to see if you all survive while subtly feed each other to the wolves. I have several games about Poland in this era. This is the best of them
#1034!

item.name: Going, Going, GONE!
item.comment: fun and chaotic, but not for me. worth trying regardless.

item.name: The Golden Ages
item.comment: Generic civ theme with a puzzle board for replayability. The game is rock solid and fun with advance society developments costing more and warfare is profitable but expensive, very cool

item.name: Gorkamorka
item.comment: Like Necromunda, only fun for a few sessions, once a heavy shoota gets introduced the game breaks down into a hopeless mess.

item.name: GOSU
item.comment: need to play several times to see if the chaos is worth getting past the obtuse rules

item.name: Gothic Invasion
item.comment:
A light war game with promise, but plagued with issues, not a multiplayer by any stretch of the imagination.
The action cards are multi-use but very generic, unlike say a more historic CDG by GMT.
I question the viability of the gothic invader goal cards. All in all it's too simple to be worth playing.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment:
The quintessential area control euro. If you haven't played it you need to. Seriously, play it, now.
Decennial edition (2006)

item.name: Gravwell: Escape from the 9th Dimension
item.comment: Fun and low complexity, but challenging. A good group game when everyone is feeling whimsical.
item.wishlistcomment: Neat title

item.name: Great Wall of China
item.comment: this is a Knizia game that is fun, but not a classic by the standards of his other games. I haven't played it in years, but that in and of itself is proof why it faded away.

item.name: The Great War
item.comment:
Another dull implementation of the warhammer system, forgettable in every way.
Like all Games Workshop products after 2002, this release was horribly un-supported and was delivered still born. I was a faithful fan of GW for decades and they failed me in every way imaginable long before this product was shit into existence. It's entirely my own fault I was even aware of this let alone purchased and read it.
Shame on me for buying this, I deserve the "1" I rated it.
item.conditiontext: rulebook in great shape

item.name: Great War at Sea, Vol. I: The Mediterranean
item.originalname: Great War at Sea: The Mediterranean
item.comment:
My copy is incomplete...grrr
I disposed of this rather than complete it. The getter choice IMO.

item.name: The Great Zimbabwe
item.comment: I like the "choose your own victory threshold" mechanism. The game is attractive, but too pricey for me to seriously consider.

item.name: Greenland
item.comment: As I mentioed in my wishlist...it encourages the extermination of the walrus...koo koo ga ju
item.wishlistcomment:
This has the entire population of Greenland AND walrus' on the cover...Phil Elklund has done it again!
It will be mind boggling as ever, but I can't say no to a walrus.

item.name: Grimoire
item.comment:
It was fun for ten minutes, the spell book / bookmark is neat, but the enjoyment fades quickly. I was intrigued, immersed and then BAM! I desperately wanted the game to end.
Eventually it did, and so did my interest in Grimoire.

item.name: The Grizzled
item.comment: I'm not a co-op fan, but I'm a fan of WWI themes. I like the gameplay and level of difficultly. Some of the hard knock cards, like "mute" are somewhat hard to abide, and there is a natural tendency to telegraph intentions, but I want to play it repeatedly.
item.wishlistcomment: WWI themed.

item.name: Ground Floor
item.comment: Decent worker placement game that will reward repeat plays, but is not "best in breed" for me. Very nice looking and flows well in form and function using "blueprint" tiles. Quality is high and mechanics are well intergrated.

item.name: Guards! Guards! A Discworld Boardgame
item.comment: Dull with 2 players, unfinish-able with 6 players. In the end it is unexciting and does not have the visual appeal to draw people in. Such a disappointment for me; the comparisons to Talsiman elude me.

item.name: Guerilla
item.comment: Need to play again, I had difficulty in making attacks and maintain defense of locations. I like the ability to play both sides, but the multi-player strategy has me flummoxed at present.

item.name: Guildhall
item.comment:
Ok set collection and action trigger game, depending on card mixes it can go back and forth a lot or be a race.
The art is a detractor for me.
Learned with the Job Faire expansion.

item.name: Guildhall: Job Faire
item.comment: More variety and screwage actions than the original set. Worth the occasional play, but again, the art is atrocious.

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment: decent light game and good for a filler moment.

item.name: The Guns of Gettysburg
item.comment: Application of Napoleon's Triumph on a subject matter that interests me personally
item.wishlistcomment:
Kickstarted
Looks very cool, more in my notice than Napoleonic renditions.

item.name: Gunship: First Strike!
item.comment:
Kickstarter...yes, I hopped on because I could, I hope it was worth it.
Well, it was worth trading (for a better game), so it's not that bad.

item.name: Hacker: Deluxe Edition
item.comment: Great for a loooong multi-player game, any fan of Illuminati would find this a familiar and entertaining game.

item.name: Haggis
item.comment: Clever trick taking game, nearly as good as Tichu.

item.name: Halma
item.comment:
an old classic that survives in memory but doesn't have much relevance against today's games.
I have a set owned by my family for 5 generations.

item.name: Hamburgum
item.comment: Medium weight game; bears multiple pays to best understand scoring opportunities and synergistic effects. Themeless to me but time well spent with friends.

item.name: Hammer of the Scots
item.comment: I will reclaim Scotland noble block by noble block! This is the best unfair game I have. Someday I might even win!

item.name: Hanabi Deluxe
item.comment: Fun co-op that can go sour if people are too obvious about advising each other, the better enjoyment is watching the intuition of each player form with uninflected communication.

item.name: Hands Down
item.comment: a game for people who are unwilling to engage in russian roulette or that game with a knife and your fingers...

item.name: Hands in the Sea
item.comment: deckbuilding in the wake of A Few Acres of Snow...I really want to get a chance to try this!
item.wishlistcomment: I like aFAoS and look forward to Mythtopia...will this offer something new?

item.name: Hangman
item.comment:
why use a pencil and paper when you can upgrade to a plastic wang doddle?
Why stop there, get a $1000 computer or tablet and get an electronic version with an angry animated victim you will eventually watch weep beg and die by your ignorance.
oh, the irony.

item.name: Hannibal Barkas
item.comment:
This is one of those games you look at on BGG and wish for at night (in english)...
Please?
After 6 years...I give up
AND THEN, JUST LIKE THAT A COPY FELL INTO MY LAP
item.wishlistcomment: Hoping anyone elects to develop and release in English.

item.name: Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage
item.comment: The pinnacle of 2 player CDG. The gameplay is challenging and full of tension, the battle cards are brilliant. A desert island treasure for me

item.name: Hapsburg Eclipse
item.comment: Solo game A-H WWI

item.name: Headache
item.comment: another roll and move that some lucky duck eventually won so we could play Risk, watch TV or just punch each other during rainy days in Buffalo.

item.name: Hearts
item.comment: an enjoyable classic game that is always a welcome filler or lunchtime game. the only downside is that in a face to face setting it requires 4 players.

item.name: The HellGame
item.comment:
Full of humor and dogma, the easily offended would do well to study religion, so they can put this game in persecutive and enjoy it.
Some chaos and variables are easy to trim out with house rules to make the game more of a tactical challenge

item.name: Hellweg westfalicus
item.comment: Dull as dirt euro game, mechanically sound and soulless with no fun.

item.name: Here I Stand
item.comment: Easily as good as Sword of Rome, perhaps more balanced and tons of interaction make this a long enthralling experience.

item.name: Heroscape Marvel: The Conflict Begins
item.comment: one too many marvel games out there, at this point this is an also ran...

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
item.comment:
rules wise, absolute dicefest, minatures are extremly varied, paint jobs are fair, but better than you'd think.
Cost-wise it depends when you stop buying. If it is your only game then you gotta have them all, let your OCD run wild. However if you like to play other games. beware the cash-hungry creep of a couple hundred bucks a year.
The terrain is the real gem here, visually exciting and full of imagination, like Legos, but the time to set up and the storage space can become daunting after awhile.
A great gateway and easy-going group game.
After a while I got off the merry-go-spending go round, and I am happier for it
item.conditiontext:
stuff available (cards included):
from Rise:
Mimring Grimnak Airborne Elite (squad) Tarn Viking Warriors (squad) Zettian Guard (squad) Marro Warriors (squad) Krav Maga Agents (squad) Izumi Samurai (squad)
From Om's Return:
Charos Brunak Su-Bak-Na
From Utgar's Rage:
Krug

item.name: Hex Hex
item.comment: a version of hot potato, we should go back to playing this with grenades.

item.name: High Frontier
item.comment: Played at BGG.con, mind bending planning and a lot of risk, no wonder my Dad loved working in Aerospace. R.I.P. Chuck, you're a hard act to follow.

item.name: High Society
item.comment: Picked up at BGG store based on player recommendation.

item.name: History of the Roman Empire
item.comment:
For $10 how lame could it be...?
Well, it turns out that I should have asked for double my money back as a stocking fee...wow this is crap.

item.name: History of the World
item.comment:
A more entertaining take on Risk as you can only do so much in each of the 7 eras and the riches of each area are variable as the game advances.
the card play adds a lot of variables that keep the game fresh

item.name: Hive
item.comment: after a steady diet of GIPF this is a great game to learn. very tight and tense. Brings out your best insights and planning. I love my Bakelite Bugs!

item.name: The Hobbit Card Game
item.comment:
Dunno, but I'm curious...least of all because I portrayed Bilbo in a middle school musical, and I was taller than all the dwarves...shag carpet spirit glued to my feet, I shit you not!
This is a pointless and dull trick taking game.

item.name: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey
item.comment: A sterile Yahtzee variant that gives no pleasure. Avoid unless your into that sort of thing...

item.name: HoldFast: Korea 1950-1951
item.comment: Very different use of the system across a narrow front, brutal early turns lead to a slog if you hold the line. Love it
item.wishlistcomment: Next title in the Holdfast system

item.name: HoldFast: Russia 1941-1942
item.comment: A fast paced campaign block wargame with low unit density. Perfect level of complexity for me.

item.name: Homesteaders
item.comment:
Fast worker placement game with a really fun auction track including a very flexible marketplace to exchange goods.
Each move resonates and you'll have to manage debt very carefully. Great gem here. Play it.

item.name: Hook!
item.comment:
Goofy fun that rewards quick dexterous play, you need decent social skills and pattern recognition to do well.
Fun for 20 minutes, but nothing I'll need to play again.

item.name: Hordes
item.comment: I practically had to pay someone to take this drek off my hands. A broken dice fest that makes WH40K seem like genius. I choose...any other game.

item.name: Horus Heresy
item.comment:
A decent update of a fairly weak wargame. If it wasn't the WH40K setting this would be forgetable.
If you own or play Stronghold; Horus Heresy does not come close to surpassing it.

item.name: Horus Heresy
item.comment: The original was a straight up wargame that looked nice, but it wasn't very good. The counters were huge and colorful and the story is excellent, but again the game is not very interesting.

item.name: A House Divided: War Between the States 1861-65
item.comment: Great, low complexity war game that has benefited from its new printing by Mayfair. I love the ramp up in complexity that the rules allows for. Excellent game.

item.name: Hundred Days 20
item.comment: Standalone deluxe battle, no mounted map, replaces Waterloo 20

item.name: Hungry Hungry Hippos
item.comment:
frantic marble gathering activity that makes a racket and is completely worth experiencing.
it is a dumb game by any measure, but you should play it..

item.name: Hybrid
item.comment: This game and the miniatures are excellent. The translation from the original French needs a little patience, but the depth of the gameplay is outstanding!

item.name: Hyperborea
item.comment:
Interesting "bag builder" with cubes for recipe filling. Enjoyable if slightly dull game of adventuring and using resources to build items, characters, VP and interact on a map. There is conflict amongst the players, but mostly over area control, not conquest.
It was a fun time with friends

item.name: I'm the Boss!
item.comment:
Chaotic and personal; not for the fragile ego as this game favors the silver-tongued.
Only dislike is the ability to steal your opponents personality...once that happans you are struggling to stay in the game until you can steal one back.

item.name: i9n
item.comment:
It sounds better than it plays which is a shame because it looks neat too. Basically you have limited information and you can bluff to throw off you opponents, but it is so slow and dull you want it to end, so bluffing is uneventful. Unfortunately the pace is dictated by the players making successful hits. In the end you must slog through till that moment or quit. I'm glad I tried it, but with nothing more involved than roll and: move, purchase or attempt...the fun is elusive.
The punch boards might be a component of a better game someday...

item.name: Ice War
item.comment: a game I remember fondly as a small press wargame with harsh rules. part of my mircogame years.

item.name: Iliad
item.comment: An excellent blind purchase! The level of player interaction is very high. The best games so far have been 2 on 2 and 4-player team play. The cards interactions are spot on and the scoring of the Hoplites is very entertaining...provided you can keep them alive. This is going to get played over and over. Each time Iliade has been played it dominates the attention of my group for hours.

item.name: Illuminati: Deluxe Edition
item.comment:
Hilarious fun, creating a paraniod fantasy of secret societies and their duped pawns.
At present the weird groups dominate winning easily. Needs tweaking to restore the balance..or you could just constantly screw with the Discordian player...just an idea.
I like it, but don't play much as reality has been much more comical of late.
item.conditiontext:
Generous Trade offer:
Deluxe Edition Y2K Brainwash Bavarian Fire Drill
All Cards are sleeved; materials are in main box.

item.name: Illuminati: New World Order
item.comment: A collectable game rooted in the illuminati theme. Not a game I would play much, nor did I, but the cards, art and concept are just too good to be dismissed lightly.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment: tough shrewd and cynical, what a wargame should really encompass. I like it.

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: Goofy art, and asymmetric resource engines. The game seems to end before you get anywhere. Clever, but seeing as I didn't really care for 51st State et al, I have not interest in keeping up with this one.

item.name: Imperial Stars II
item.comment: VPG deluxe space themed wargamr

item.name: In Flanders Field
item.comment:
Not unlike Can't Stop, but given you are sacrificing lives for distance, a much more visceral theme.
The art is stupendous and while the game play is light, as a commemorative of the 100th anniversary of the beginning of WWI in cooperation with the Imerial War Museum, this is a great gaming experience and I'm happy to have it in my collection.

item.name: In Magnificent Style
item.comment: VPG deluxe production with chit draw mechanic

item.name: Infamy
item.comment:
Buzz interest, no real feedback yet...
After playing I see why some folks might enjoy it, but I found no theme, and little if any interaction. If in fact this is a crime and scheming game, then the future is a very sanitized and sterile place.
item.wishlistcomment: Cyberpunk comic book art, so, it is worth playing?

item.name: Infection: Humanity's Last Gasp
item.comment: VPG deluxe production, Solo alternative to pandemic

item.name: Infinite City
item.comment:
Entertaining chaos...seems like too much stuff going on for 6 players to do anything strategic other than go unnoticed till the game halts.
I could see this being much more fasinating with 3 or 4 players.

item.name: Infinity
item.comment: Yet another take on a d20 minis game. Highly detailed and chock full of diverse and pricy minis I could not get past the ridiculous themes and extreme need for elaborate terrain. If it surpasses Warzone it will speak highly of the system, but I'll remain a skeptical observer.
item.conditiontext: 1st edition hardcover in english, full color

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment:
A great tactical abstract that falls victim to too many players. As a 2-player it is a true challenge. Multi-player drags in my opinion.
I strongly suggest the travel edition.

item.name: Ingenious: Travel Edition
item.comment: An awesome 2-player that is a tight contest. The pieces are perfectly produced to offer a travel edition worthy of the moniker "travel edition"

item.name: Innovation
item.comment: I recognize the cleverness, but I find the game so souless and unfun I have no need to sit through one more go.

item.name: Inquisitor
item.comment: Pathetic game with lovely minis. I can't say I played it much, but neither did the rest of the world.

item.name: Into the Bastards!: First tank battle
item.comment:
Very interesting endgame scenario during the last gasps of Operation Michael. The German attack is very daunting and as the British defenders you'll feel disaster approaching. As the casualties build from and-to-hand the IGO-YouGO is swapped out for Chit Draws...and the the Australians jump in and all hell is unleashed...
add this to your copies of Marne 1918 and Somme 1918

item.name: Intrigue
item.comment: Mean game that is distilled down to plain old mean. No urge to play again as it fosters butt-hurt

item.name: INWO SubGenius
item.comment:
Crappy computer art design...J.R.. "Bob" Dobbs must be turning in his art deco, paste-up grave.
Fun cards, but undone by art devoid of all joy.

item.name: Italia
item.comment: Revised edition of Anzio

item.name: Ivanhoe
item.comment: Entertaining light fair for a Knizia design. The quality of the cards is good and it makes for decent filler. There are a lot better to be sure.

item.name: JAB: Realtime Boxing
item.comment: chaotic and fun, but not a staple for me. I like the gameplay and tempo. I'm not "fast" enough to have any strategy, so the occasional play will do me just fine.

item.name: Jacks
item.comment:
A traditional experience that is a cornerstone of dexterity games.
It is not a game to play into adulthood

item.name: James Ernest's Totally Renamed Spy Game
item.comment:
a truely stupid one-note joke of a game heralded by cheap gamers that would rather play crap games.
I hated playing this...and I refuse.

item.name: Jaws
item.comment: its like Barrel of Monkey's and Operation mixed. the beast will swallow you whole...not really, but it was fun to play then as it is stupid now.

item.name: Jenga
item.comment: kinda funny how off kilter this can get, but the joy is in watching someone fail. the destruction of the tower is delightful, especially when it is not your turn.

item.name: Joan of Arc's Victory 1429 AD
item.comment:
Honeymoon option...will I be won over to buy the whole set?
So annoyed with the quality of the series I threw this at a game collector to bury on some obscure shelf in his Bunker of Shame

item.name: Julius Caesar
item.comment:
for me this ends up being "just another (Blank)" I love the history behind the game, but the play balance seems off and there seems no way to convey the politics that made this conflict so interesting.
The straw that breaks it for me is the event cards that are automatic...at least in HotS you have to roll to turn a block.

item.name: Junta
item.comment: You got Fun in my Diplomacy! Hurt feelings are softened by amusing card plays. Some people will relentless kill each other while the winner will slink quietly to the bank early and often.
item.wishlistcomment: Hoping they back off on the day-glo look...

item.name: Junta: Viva el Presidente!
item.comment: chaotic and amusing "take-that" gameplay, a good opener or late nite drinking filler game...nothing particularly compelling, but it's worth an occasional session.

item.name: Jupiter Rescue
item.comment: A coop with robots saving dumb ass humans from aliens that basically represent creeping crud. Rinsh wash repeat...did we lose yet?

item.name: Just a Peiper Dream?
item.comment: Given away, crap

item.name: The Kaiser's Pirates
item.comment: Boring and ridiculously long, I tried to find the fun and failed. Nothing compelling and the art while accurate it is too small to give any sense of the ship-types or the development of modern naval combat.

item.name: Kanban: Automotive Revolution
item.comment:
Played a prototype, very challenging actions and timing with a non-player piece that moves at a pace depending on the players action selection, and then moves in initiative order with the players.
Very promising on my first play, but I did have a hard time anticipating the end or planning for the final scoring...there seems to be very little incentive to spend shifts to get to the top of the progress tracks first as the point bonus seems wasted against saving for other uses and scoring opportunities.
Overall I really liked the variety of different systems in each department, and I look forward to the entire game getting tighter as feedback is processed.
item.wishlistcomment: the irony of a resource management game about process efficiency is not lost on me...

item.name: Kashgar: H√§ndler der Seidenstra√üe
item.comment:
Interesting sequence of card plays churning through 3 seperate card stacks to trigger actions or collect resources as you acquire point scoring cards. A fun game with limited interaction, but some rather clever card actions.
Try it and see

item.name: Kemet
item.comment:
Very pretty, low complexity area control wargame. an excellent effort that has a broad appeal. The winner is the person who sticks to a consistent strategy and can husband their score well enough not to wear a neon sign declaring they are too far ahead.
Turn order and resource management are key. Tracking of victory point sources is very well done in a manner that initially seemed superfluous, but proved to be crucial information when vying for the win.
Attacking is not only encouraged but rewarded as a primary source of VP. Area control is also rewarded at key locations with synergistic bonus VP.
Very cool, best of all it is not related to Cyclades as I feared.
item.wishlistcomment: Anticipated Spring 2013

item.name: Ker Plunk
item.comment: the cause and effect of removing one stick one at a time is tense and way more fun than Jenga or Don't Break the Ice.

item.name: Key Market
item.comment: Worker placement, comodities market with special powers locations and exclusive titles. I like the initiative system (fewest workers). This one is about timing and forming a strategy before you start. Very unforgiving if you lose focus even for 1 turn.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment: Neat for 3 or 4, but utter chaos and seating opportunity action theft with 5 & 6. I like the quick playtime, but more plays with 3 may refine my impressions.

item.name: Kill Shot
item.comment: An annoying speed game of random draws, punctuated by interrupts that slow up the game rather than hinder one player. Basically a waste of time and money.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment:
Kayleigh's copy.
a fun push-your-luck romp with huge chunky dice. the game doesn't outstay it's welcome and gets people laughing and rooting for everyone. ends so quick, there is no time to be resentful about player elimination.

item.name: King Oil
item.comment: Another childhood game with a gimmick...unfortunately it does not hold up well and after 10 minutes you'll be praying for it to end, but it just won't die. My advice, let the wookie win and play something else.

item.name: Kingdoms
item.comment: Light filler from the early days of Fantasy Flight.

item.name: Kittens in a Blender
item.comment:
a silly cardgame in the tradition of Poo. this time it is cute fluff in a blender. WHHIRRR
this is part of Kayleigh's collection.

item.name: Kolejka
item.comment: Great mix of history and design, with lots of play jockeying for position in a line for unknown outcomes. The fact that you may be fighting for a worthless reward is the irony of the period this game represents.

item.name: Kremlin
item.comment:
Comedic and nasty in equal measure, a fun, but overly long role selection game.
The back-stabiness is a great time with animated people.
A redesign and re-release would entice me.
item.wishlistcomment: Waiting on the new reprint

item.name: Kremlin (Limited Edition)
item.comment:
The game looks great and the new options are really cool!
The new version is nice, but has some warts, the biggest among them is the card print errors. The publisher is a really nice person, but the handling of the error was mismanaged. ALL of the Kickstarter backers should have automatically received corrected cards, not those that asked for them.
Something to be mindful of in the future.

item.name: Kulami
item.comment: New too me, requires a bit of joint memory to keep the game together...probably needs some markers to aid the absent-minded. The scoring is deceptive, but leads to new strategies.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment:
When you first play you think you need to be subtle with fine motor control. Not true! The person who regularly wins learns to use wild twists of the knobs and extreme angles to keep the ball away from the holes. Dumb.
Very cool looking regardless of my desire to ever play it again.

item.name: Labyrinth: The War on Terror, 2001 ‚Äì ?
item.comment: Hand management with unpredictable card draws and events. The terrorist sneaks everywhere while the US pays Whack-a-Mole. Not how I'd spend my afternoons. See his better efforts Andean Abyss or Wilderness War

item.name: Lagoon: Land of Druids
item.comment: Clever abstract that is very beutiful in the art level that resembles MtG

item.name: Lancaster
item.comment: Ok game I probably should play again. Sadly there was no theme, and that lessened my interest early on.

item.name: Lascaux: Exploring Ancestral Art
item.comment: fun set collection auction game, but it cannot top No Thanks!

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment:
Understandably, this game was well promoted at the recent cons, and the theme is a traditional one that has a considerable fan base. Regardless the game mechanics are the stuff of true nightmares. Near every aspect of the game relies on dice and randomness. Initally this doesn't seem to bother the early adopters of these types of games, but eventually the bloom fades and people realize what they have, another dicefest-hangover.
I've been in recovery from many similar episodes, and having been treated to a few rounds by a friend who caved in and bought this, I will live to see many more nights on this earth than LNOE will.
We gave it another shot, the dice rolling was painful...

item.name: Last Train to Wensleydale
item.comment: Due to the merge with 1st Train to Nurmberg, my rating is here, the art of the original is dreadful...but the games are a treat to play, very challenging.

item.name: Last Will
item.comment:
Fun and light, with a nice amount of indirect screwage. Blowing cash as opposed to hording is a novel approach. I need to play it more because I made some bad investments that made money (ugh).
Buying property that devalues a lot seems ideal over property with spending actions.

item.name: Leaping Lemmings
item.comment: Fun with alcohol, but not for long...you'll find yourself hoping you've thrown yourself off a cliff long before you reach the edge...throw this off instead.

item.name: Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy
item.comment: Lots of attention on this, a must play for BGG.con
item.wishlistcomment: Wait or buy, maybe play?

item.name: Letnisko
item.comment:
Initially I passed on this, but on second thought I really want to get this to the table regularly.
I'm really glad I located a copy, this is a fun and light worker placement card game that doesn't overstay it's welcome. I like the use of a weather mechanic for shifting supply of vacationers.

item.name: Letter of Marque
item.comment: one of the weakest throwaway games ever designed by Bruno Faidutti...shocking that he'd sell it to someone and equally sad that FFG thought it was worth publishing.

item.name: Letters from Whitechapel
item.comment:
Kayleigh's copy.
Tense, involving and thematic. When murder as motivation is presented against one of the most famous unsolved crimes, it gets personal trying to win as either side in this contest.

item.name: Leuthen: Frederick's Greatest Victory 5 December, 1757
item.comment: VPG deluxe production, intrigued

item.name: Liar's Dice
item.comment: Fun, but imperfect game that plays well with a large group, but player elimination sucks

item.name: Libertalia
item.comment: Multiplayer role selection with shifting player powers and end of round scoring. Kind of fun and worth trying.

item.name: Libert√©
item.comment: wonderful update visually, as always Liberte is yet another great way to make new enemies at the table.

item.name: Little Devils
item.comment: I like trick taking games, but this one is too lite for me, it found a better home.

item.name: Lock 'n Load: Heroes of the Blitzkrieg
item.comment: Great game in the early part of the war. The fun is in fighting from a disadvantage looking to hold the German player at bay.

item.name: London
item.comment: a light game that is Wallace to the core. I was initially put off by the talk of how light this game played. I was wrong in my assumptions, it is a great game, it plays clean, fast and fun.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment: Visually stunning and evocative co-op. One of my favorite group games.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
item.comment: outclassed by the deluxe version, but still a great game

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment: the fastest LOTR game out there, and that makes it near the best. Only bested by the Co-op version.

item.name: Lords of Scotland
item.comment:
Set collection, special powers with a descending value rule and atrociously written rules made my first play un-satisfying. It's probably worth the effort to play it again, but this can't compare to games like Battle Line or No Thanks!
Post script after my annoying session, I do see the possible strategy of collecting cards waiting for decent victory points.

item.name: Lords of Vegas
item.comment:
an Aquire-like grid with a boatload of chaos involved. Best with good-humored folk who love completely screwing with each other. There is strategy and strong theme and a lot of unfairness...so much so that it works really well.
not for the serious or timid

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: Light worker placement with great art. The theme is carried somewhat with one small note in my head...there is no risk of failing a quest. To me a fantasy adventure theme needs some peril to meet my needs. Where is the epic glory? Not here.

item.name: Lords of Xidit
item.comment: An annoying dopey game with a nuisance level of over the top components. Such a waste of time moving around the board gathering resources and defeating monsters by discarding your resources...since the resources are all differnt types of people I assume they are all casualties, which seems kinda incredible...who would follow a leader who loses all of his follows in every battle...stupid.

item.name: Lost Battles
item.comment: A detailed board game with heavy duty components. As I understand the rules it seems like gameplay is very similar to many miniatures systems I have played...can't wait to try it.

item.name: Lost Battles: Reconstructing the Great Clashes of the Ancient World
item.comment: Dry, but interesting read, I will only play it via the boardgame, no interest in getting into miniatures again.

item.name: Lost Legacy: Flying Garden
item.comment: Long form Love Letter with Player elimination, a lot of people react negatively to this short game...very odd responses

item.name: Lost Legacy: Second Chronicle ‚Äì Vorpal Sword & Whitegold Spire
item.comment: Looking to see how these new sets integrate with the previous 2, shame they changed the format...why not velvety sack?

item.name: Lost Legacy: The Starship
item.comment: First in the series of Live Letter games with an actual theme, expansions inbound.

item.name: Lost Temple
item.comment:
Race game using the Citadels role selection mechanic. It's not Mission Red Planet, or Citadels...
It is definitely light and is full of back stabbing. A filler for most people.

item.name: Louis XIV
item.comment: A clever game I need to get to the table again soon.

item.name: Love Letter: The Hobbit ‚Äì The Battle of the Five Armies
item.comment: Ok if a not downright stale,I still prefer the original as a game...this adds very little.

item.name: Love Letter: Wedding Edition
item.comment: Celebrating with Jim and Jane Williamson

item.name: Lunch Money
item.comment: a mean-spirited theme with equally disturbing cards. I thought it was sorta fun, but some folks took it a tad to seriously and it put me off playing with them.

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment: A fast luck based version of Dominion...rather stupid IMO, but it's over so fast that I can't complain, much.

item.name: Machine of Death: The Game of Creative Assassination
item.comment: Wow, just plain awful...kickstarted crap

item.name: Madeira
item.comment: From the authors of Panamax, supposedly one of the best most difficult game out there?...

item.name: Mafia City
item.comment:
Is it available or just a fantasy?
I've played it, tis fun, but needed more development to keep it interesting.
item.wishlistcomment: Theme and playtime attracted me

item.name: Mage Knight
item.comment: Wow, what a low quality cash drain that left me hanging, I should have known better, so it was my own fault. In the end these minis are worth less than then plastic; true crap.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment:
Good as solo and multiplayer race. The adventure dynamic and ever changing with each play. It might take forever to hit the bottom of this box.
I find this too slow and solitary as a game.

item.name: Mage Knight Dungeons
item.comment:
Hahaha the joke is on me! Not only did I collect the whole set, but then the game suddenly disappeared! Man oh man am I a silly fool.
Will I learn? sadly not very likely...

item.name: Mage Wars
item.comment:
Very reminiscent of a tactical miniatures game I enjoyed, Confrontation (v3.5, Rackham). Lots of special rules and counter special rules that will have players flipping through reference sheets and debating nuances of game effects. All in all a good game that may take a lot of plays to become manageable.
The deck construction can be a hobby in itself similar to army building in games like WH40K.
It's main appeal is the low cost of entry compared to actual miniatures, but I can see some players or the company itself gradually introducing minis eventually.
It takes up a lot of real estate on your table.

item.name: Magic Realm
item.comment:
no, I couldn't figure out how to play it either...so pretty, but at age 10 the rules made me turn to Tunnels & Trolls, Melee and Dungeons & Dragons which were vastly easier to learn.
Looking at it now, I have no regrets.

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment:
Magic is something unique in the world of fads and disposable games...a CCG that defies the criticism of jaded tools like me. Say what you want, but almost all of us play or have played it and we all have the scars to prove it.
Many adults still fly too close to the sun spending time with other people's kids at distances that border on inappropriate touching gleefully discussing card effects and rarity values with passion that resembles obsessive sports fandom.
Is it wrong? How would I know? I'm on the inside laughing at a subset of my own hobby. Yes I think it is stupid to constantly repurchase sets of cards because of the MtG tournament regulations, just like it is stupid to buy a new army with each revised WH codex. been there done that.
In the end is it harmful? No! It serves as an effective means of birth control by regulating the social habits of people that probably should not reproduce - ever. How else are you gonna keep these kids penned on Fridays and Saturday's without violating their rights. I say let 'em buy more cards and boost the economy while at the same time not muddying the gene pool with more kids with OCD.
Then again, there may also be a side benefit to all this...the next evolution of math geniuses may come from the ranks of the Magic players...could it be a covert op to unlock the next Einstein or Mandelbrot? Only J. Edgar Hoover's disembodied head knows for sure.
item.conditiontext: Knights and Dragons play decks, sleeved with premium "Magic" art sleeves

item.name: The Magnates: A Game of Power
item.comment:
Rinse-wash-repeat game with area majority game with levels of cooperation and competition...very hard to put your own interests below the national needs, great levels of fuckery.
Excellent
item.wishlistcomment:
A game based on a game based on God's Playground? How could I say no?
What can I say? The true design innovations come from Poland!

item.name: Mag¬∑Blast
item.comment: a few plays and you are done...

item.name: Mag¬∑Blast (Second Edition)
item.comment:
played slightly better than the first edition. eventually this died for me.
Remember: you've gotta make the noise if you want your hits to count.

item.name: Mahjong
item.comment: A great pick-up game that plays well with all ages, nice sets look fabulous and feel great when handled

item.name: Major Battles and Campaigns of General George S. Patton
item.comment:
A little more open than the same game system for MacArthur. I can't say I liked it as I found the retreat rules a little wonky - you can retreat forward...which I didn't like one bit.
Given its age I should be kind and play it a few more times...but so many other games to enjoy. If only I discovered it when I was a kid.

item.name: Major Campaigns of General Douglas MacArthur
item.comment: Fun, not amazing given its age, but some of the scenarios are very tense and the action point mechanic is novel and challenging.

item.name: Malifaux
item.comment:
Giving the Outcasts a first try, going with the Victorias.
My friend is going with the Guild - Lady Justice and her Death Marshals.

item.name: Mall of Horror
item.comment: Played it years ago, I remember the overall sensation of panic in deciding where to go and the scheming of who to kill. Very amusing stuff.

item.name: Man O' War
item.comment: one of GW great designs, so of course it failed to survive...sickening
item.conditiontext: Box split in one corner Rulebook missing; photocopy provided 2 Turning Template replaced with plasticard added photo copy of all White Dwarf Articles added photocopies of control cards and campaign sheets

item.name: Man to Man
item.comment:
The further development of the combat system of Melee and the precursor of GURPS.
More of a curiosity now.

item.name: Mancala
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
Learn it and move on.

item.name: Manhattan
item.comment:
A nice looking game that is mean and cutthroat you'll never see what I mean until you play it yourself.
Sublime, short and fantastically mean. I love it.

item.name: Manoeuvre
item.comment: I wish I liked this better, but I don't. It plays like a simple miniatures game mixed with a "command and colors" like system. Add in that the forces are of so much mixed qualities that random pairings can end badly. The game just is not compelling.
item.conditiontext: Sealed

item.name: Mansions of Madness
item.comment:
there are tons of things in the box...the Lovecraft theme is far stronger here than in Arkham Horror and the session time is more managable.
Set-up time from a cold start is quite long and very specific, but that is to the benefit of future replay of the 5 scenarios.
Both the Investigators and the Keeper need to stay "in character" reading the flavor text to tie all of the things going on here in context of the story.
two annoying things...the repeated Horror checks for monsters can get tedious, and the combat deck "draw till you match your attack type" is clunky at best.
Overall not bad, Still prefer Witch of Salem when I crave the end of everything, but Masions of Madness does deliver on its premise.
NOTE: If you want to get the most mileage out of this one; DON"T READ THE CARDS WHEN YOU ARE NOT PLAYING...they are "things man was not meant to know."

item.name: Marbles
item.comment: At one time I owned an enviable marble collection, so beutiful, I wish I knew what happened to them

item.name: Mare Nostrum
item.comment:
a lovely Mediterranean Civ/Conquest game that has components that raise the bar on what games should look like.
It has faded for some and is out of print at the moment. I could easily see someone like FFG reviving this someday, just hope they don't ass up the components with more components.

item.name: Nothing Personal
item.comment:
Based only on gameplay...I'm in no hurry to play this again. It's not about the chaotic shenanigans, but the strategies that I think are repeatable and difficult to overcome. By focusing my influence on a limited number of gangsters (no more than 3) and spending every free dollar to "up the ante" I was able to weaken players who either passed or felt compelled to sacrifice cards to play, only making them weaker in subsequent turns. I never sweat a character going to jail or getting whacked, and only messed with other players gangsters when it was a secondary effect of card play or board position.
I had plenty of money, scored more points each turn and had better card choices by virtue of more cards to choose from. If everyone played this way the game might balance, but I think that would make the game stale as it seems that the more risky actions are a distraction from a coherent strategy. Players banding together to slow down one player quickly reveal the next "leader" and around and around we go...all in all this game wasn't a disaster and was worth playing once.
I'll stick with Kremlin, Junta and Dune. IMO each of these games are more focused and rewarding to play.
Lastly, the production issues and some of the font choices are bewildering...most specifically the cursive writing was almost unreadable. So many delightful component choices are undone by poor graphics choices and shameful editing.

item.name: Nothing So Well Lost: The Siege of Rhodes 1522
item.comment:

item.comment: I don't know what to say...other than the art is horrible and the game is exceedingly dull. bleech

item.name: Ogre
item.comment:
This is the Y2K combined edition, the penultimate version of the original game.
an underrated classic intro to hex and counter wargames. That being said it does not compare to modern designs like Command and Colors and Hannibal RvC.
Antiquted or not this was the anchor of my love affair with gaming. Without OGRE/G.E.V. and many other Metagaming favs I'm not sure I would have transitioned into gaming as a hobby.

item.name: Ogre
item.comment: My first wargame...squee!!!

item.name: Ogre Miniatures
item.comment: Great minatures traslation of OGRE and G.E.V. as an asides the fact that they took the trouble to do a full color rulebook with tons of pictures in 1992 speak highly of the love SJGames have for their signature games. I also love that they provided a rationalization for scale that ends any arguements regarding realism.

item.name: Ogre: Deluxe Edition
item.comment:
This is the Minatures set for the original game released in 2000.
it is a dinosaur that deserves it's rightful place as one of the best and cheapest wargames made for new wargamers. If you were gaming in 1977 you played this and loved it. If you were born later, you should play it.

item.name: Ogre: Deluxe Edition
item.comment: this is the original Deluxe Edition - with the large counters and the OGRE control markers on the board.

item.name: Ogre: Designer's Edition
item.comment: OGRE as is never was and will be hereafter!
item.wishlistcomment:
April 12, 2012. Wonders be praised, SJG looked to Kickstarter to feel the love...it's looking like they are going to make this grander than any game I own. Is this Irony?
Late 2011 - this is dragging out so long it may become another in a long list of games I have looked forward to only to realize that the publisher has very different priorities from myself.

item.name: Ogre: Pocket Edition
item.comment:
I have owned many copies and many editions...this is where hobby gaming all started for me.
Even my jaded heart still has room for this old soldier

item.name: Okko: Era of the Asagiri
item.comment:
a good-looking, fast playing combat game that is similar to Hybrid and Tannhauser, but ultimately boring as each game ends in a landslide defeat for one side as soon as you are outnumbered.
I really dislike opposed die-roll systems, this game brings the preference for other systems into sharp relief.
I like the comics though, good reading, dumb game

item.name: Old Maid
item.comment: Another light card game that teaches rules and limited strategy...it also inspires cheating through marking cards :)

item.name: On the Underground
item.comment: great looking game I picked up for the visual appeal. I work in the Mass Transit industry and the concept is by extension captivating.

item.name: One Night Revolution
item.comment: Completely forgettable version of One Night Werewolf...wait...what was I talking about?

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
Novel kickstarter with near immediate gratification to be released at BGG.con '13. Couldn't resist.

item.name: Onirim
item.comment:
hand management game that while clever, is not entirely satisfying. the artwork is grating after a while.
not my brand of nightmare i guess

item.name: Onslaught: D-Day to the Rhine
item.comment:
Fun game, with early use of variable impulse, initiative tests as well as a turn end test - concepts that are part of modern designs. It also has a low counter density for such a large board.
It is easy to learn and alternate strategies emerged after my initial mistakes.

item.name: Onward to Venus
item.comment:
No clue, but I loved touring the author's website
Treefrog subscription 2014
I got really excited and tracked down all three graphic novels. They are a delight to read through.

item.name: Operation
item.comment: my aspirations of a medical career ended with this dude dying because I failed to remove his wishbone with sufficient skill.

item.name: Operation Cerberus: The Channel Dash
item.comment: Postcard game...yes I gave this one away too

item.name: Ophidian 2350
item.comment: Disposable card deck handed out at BGG.con...no joy here

item.name: Ophir
item.comment:
Ok if not dissapointing, very dependent on turn order IMO. There is quite a sense of repetition due to the small board. Now to be fair the minimal board keep the play length down, but it's no fun to simply go round and around and back and forth over the same 7 hexes.
I think the dice mechanic for moving through an opponent is tedious. Failing the die rolls a few times is a guarantee of failure with no option to recover.

item.name: Origins: How We Became Human
item.comment:
a deep game that requires intense analysis to understand the value in the chaos of each turn, turning tragedy into advantage and becoming the dominate homonid is mean and necessary.
how often i will play is going to be dependant on getting past the crappy rulebook...truth be told I don't ever want to pay it again.

item.name: Ortus Regni
item.comment:
I'm not sure this was fun...it plays logically, and it looks great, but it also seems very linear in strategic depth. The advantage for this game will be in customizing player decks and having asymmetrical contests.
The rulebook seems overwrought, but every rule seems to be in a logical place. It might sucumb to luck of the draw, as a much needed card fails to appear.

item.name: Othello
item.comment: A basic abstract that has many plays in my past, eclipsed by the GIPF series, but worth learning.

item.name: Ottoman Sunset
item.comment: Solo Ottoman Empire WWI

item.name: The Outcast Heroes
item.comment: Yet another game from Poland I want to play!
item.wishlistcomment: Yet one more cool game from Poland...a trend I think...

item.name: Outpost
item.comment:
heavy duty update-reprint of a classic I never played back in the day.
I'm not fully enthused by the snowball economics of this game, but I do enjoy the game if only for the company of my friends and the simplicity of the rules.

item.name: P.I.
item.comment: Fun and tense race to see who can solve their cases quickest without error. The board is visually lovely, but busy for some folks. I really like it regardless.

item.name: Pacific Typhoon
item.comment:
horrible version of indian poker where the first player to declare sides is the person most likely to lose each time.
fuck no. horrible.

item.name: Packet Row
item.comment:
Seems like the rose dropped off the bloom here...interest low.
This is a forgettable euro in a sea of average games

item.name: Pamplona: Viva San Ferm√≠n!
item.comment: Nice components and well themed. A filler race game that can be completed very quickly. Basically you either use your beef to protect your runner to score points or you trample and kill your opponents. The winner is the player who knows which strategy to open with...and when to change up to secure victory.

item.name: Panamax
item.comment:
P11/2013 Still in prototype, but one of coolest new designs.
Post Essen '13 - First played this at Metatopia as a test for Stronghhold. Loved it.
BGG.con '13 - Took a prototype to the con, played it, collected feedback, relayed to the designers
2014 - asked by Stronghold to take the role of Developer for Panamax working directly with the Design team.
Yes, I still love the game, the designers (Gil, Nuno and Paulo) are phenomenal collaborative creators.
item.wishlistcomment: Development complete release date scheduled for possible GenCon '14...definitely for Essen '14

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: New edition of classic co-op
item.wishlistcomment: Will the art and the new cards warrant a purchase...I sort of doubt it.

item.name: Pandemic: The Cure
item.comment:
Removing the game board and speeding up player actions by the use of dice takes me out of the game completely, couldn't wait for it to end.
In no way does this improve or replace Pandemic...this is forgettable.

item.name: Panic Station
item.comment:
Some tension, but player AP where it served no purpose dragged this intial play and lowered my enthusiasism a great deal. If it had been role-playing and negotiation I would have been intrigued, but alas it t'was but a brain fart.
In the end the infected person was not even the AP player, he lost by "trying to be unpredictable"...the group I played in made for a horrible introduction.

item.name: Panzergruppe Guderian
item.comment: Classic wargame with variable quality Russian units that are a mystery to both players till they are engaged. Excellent

item.name: Parade
item.comment: Entertaining card game with 6 suits and 11 values (0-10). The goal is a low score when the deck runs out. These cards are in a line and each play seeks to lengthen the line or take cards strategically. Poor play nets you lots of cards...

item.name: Paris Connection
item.comment:
Fast and aggressive with slick gameplay...couldn't be simpler and still constitute a game, but oh, what a game - with only 2 action choices; you have to commit to expand your shares, hoping someone else builds the same color, or build track to increase the value of a train line yourself knowing everyone else can ride your coattails profiting off of your effort by taking shares themselves, perhaps preventing you from sharing in the success!
Love it.

item.name: Pasha
item.comment:
The dice are very hard to read due to weird choice of watermarking and pip style.
As a game it is a joyless exercise even after one round. Dreadful to play

item.name: Pass the Pigs
item.comment:
played drunk, this is a game. sober this is a sad affair with a surprisingly large number of people that seem to know the rules.
I love bacon too, but this is stupid.

item.name: Patchistory
item.comment: It's either the uber-hype of the show or the must have game of Essen '13
item.wishlistcomment:
The "Denied!" Game of Essen...50 copies...are you fucking kidding me?
Available for preorder

item.name: Patchwork
item.comment: A great puzzler with aspects of Thebes. Simple and replayable. Maybe the best thing I've ever played by Uwe Rosenberg.

item.name: Paths of Glory
item.comment:
This is the highest level of complexity in a wargame I can manage. That being said I love the gameplay and it models historical limitations without getting bogged down by restrictive historical scripting.
A triumph of CDG design that stands as one of the best 2-player games.

item.name: Pax Porfiriana
item.comment: I've fallen down the Phil Eklund rabbit hole. Great card game, significantly more approachable than Lords of the Sierra Madre
item.wishlistcomment: I'm warming up to Sierra Madre Games, they no longer seem so daunting.

item.name: Pay Day
item.comment:
a family boardgame that is ok, perhaps more fun than monopoly, but easily thrown over for much better games.
i think every american family in the last 30 years had this in their game closet...if they ever played games that is.

item.name: Pay Dirt
item.comment:
Dislike the strict rules of the auction. I liked the wear on the equipment, but there are a lot of games I'd rather play.
It's nice to see this game come out as a unique theme, but I doubt I'll play it often.

item.name: Paying the Peiper
item.comment: Stick these games up your peiper!

item.name: Peloponnes
item.comment:
A variation on the auction mechanics found in Outpost and Ra. I discovered both Outpost and Pelaponnes in roughly the same timeframe and while Peloponnes is a newer game with advancement in design and play time I am not a fan. I just found this to be a stale exercise.
I much prefer the guts, intimidation and simplicity of Ra as an Auction Game.

item.name: Perfection
item.comment: the box art said it all. we used to just let the timer run out to watch the pieces jump.

item.name: Pergamon
item.comment: a fun lightish game with decent theme. I enjoy going playing it well enough, but I'm more a fan of Thebes in almost every sense.

item.name: Perikles
item.comment: I've not had enough plays to ariculate how I feel about this. a solid wargame, but not enthralling. I really need another session to define it.

item.name: Pickup Sticks
item.comment: another dexterity game that was common, in retrospect how was this fun?

item.name: Pirates of the Spanish Main
item.comment: the ships are great the rules once tweeked are good enough, but the original rules really suck!

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment: Excellent ridiculous fun that is always a hit, best if slightly inebriated and never for more than 2 hours. I love the customized stuff that can be added with a little effort and a woodshop.

item.name: Pittsburgh 68
item.comment:
Ok...I get it, Zombies sell copies. I however am not a Zombie, so when I play a game that makes me feel like my life essence is draining away I tend to pick another game to play. A party game with Zombies means only one thing...
The Downtime of The Dead...
Oh yeah, mediocre components, crappy art, but hey it's got Zombies...bleech

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment:
The loveliest game in my collection with solid gameplay built around supply/demand market prices and role selection. Great with 5 players. the components are worth the purchase price. very tactile...mmmm
forget sheep, I've got wood for Lady Steam

item.name: Plunder
item.comment: Great Packaging and starts off as a fun card/board game, but it fails to keep anyone's attention. If you are a pirate enthusiast (sp?) I guess you will enjoy it more. I gave a good home.

item.name: Pocket Battles: Macedonians vs. Persians
item.comment:
Fun and light wargame with a Left, Center, Right alternating activation sequence. Army construction is longish and rewards minmaxing. Easily breakable by a miniatures gamer, but short enough to still be fun.
The game would benefit from scenarios and some sort of terrain element.

item.name: Pocket Imperium
item.comment:
Short programming game with deterministic combat. Timing and guessing on programming the three common orders is crucial.
Victory is dependent on maximizing the benefit of occupying the center of the board.
Ok, for 30 minutes, it's very bland. The only asymmetry is the layout of the planets and your starting location.

item.name: Poker
item.comment: Next to Hearts, Poker is my favorite trad. card game, I typically play friendly low-stakes neighborhood poker.

item.name: Polis: Fight for the Hegemony
item.comment:
Really looking forward to seeing this on my game table this year!
The quality is outstanding...time to get this one played!
Stay tuned...

item.name: Poltava's Dread Day: The Great Northern War 1700-1722 AD
item.comment:
Honeymoon option...will I be won over to buy the whole set?
These are the battles that arguably define the history of the world, but this series is pathetic.

item.name: Ponzi Scheme
item.comment:
Simple enough to be too simple....basically stay one step ahead of the rest of the players and gather cash or investment tiles until one person makes a mistake.
Entertaining concept, but not a lot of depth. I did like the bribe/matching/sell mechanic, but there's not a lot going on here.
item.wishlistcomment: I hope that the gameplay is good. The topic is cynically interesting.

item.name: Popular Front
item.comment:
A very abstract way of looking at a very chaotic event. Amazingly it works; if you understand the history you can feel the distillation of the conflict in the actions and combat resolution.
Major +++ for the card art (outstanding) and the graphic design.
A shame about the quality of the disks and the "warpiness" of the board (will it ever lay flat?)
only improvements I would hope for...a means of player control over initiative (similar to the politics phase perhaps) and unique player powers (which I already suggested in the forum thread on expansions)
A new favorite, one that has me looking very seriously at this publishers other games.
10/3/12 Update: this is my favorite multi-player by adding the Escalation expansion addressing everything this game needed to become a classic. The combat is tense and the gameplay is very thematic with subtle rules for asymmetric semi cooperative factions.
Don't pass this game up.

item.name: Potato Man
item.comment: A take on trick taking that I could do without. It has some amusing trump actions with the red cards, but I'd rather teach a child Euchre or Hearts and bypass this altogether.

item.name: Power & Weakness
item.comment:
not a light game at all, this seeming filler game is a brain-burner that make me question my own sanity. how did this get to be so hard...I have no clue, but I saved myself by letting this get away from me and torture someone else.
"shudder"

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment:
the auction portion of the game is great, but the rest of the game seems to leave me very cold. I prefer games that reward good instincts, like Martin Wallace's Brass: "he who spends least goes first" as opposed to this sequence "he who appears to be falling behind goes first"
worth play once a year at best; Funny Friends is better, as that game is all-auction and instinct based.
Re-visited: this is an evergreen title, my whining about anything in this game is to be ignored.

item.name: Power Grid deluxe: Europe/North America
item.comment: Updated and tweaked version, plays great, but I miss the garbage
item.wishlistcomment: Collecting or for play? I hope I'll figure it out before I spend money on it.

item.name: Powerboats
item.comment:
I like the dice, but this game is a dopey version of Mississippi Queen and Formula D.
Mostly amusing for the hilarious overcorrections you make to stay on the course.

item.name: Praetor
item.comment:
Buzz interest, no real feedback yet...
Played a print n play version, it's a resource management and tile action game, the theme comes through and the dice placement and worker retirement subsystem is very well implemented.
item.wishlistcomment: Released or in prototype Essen 2013

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment:
tough game that is good to play, but oddly doesn't hit the table as time passes. Some good games just fade from view.
Deserves it's high rank dispite being played infrequently.

item.name: Princes of the Renaissance
item.comment:
A grail game for me if there ever was one. Actually most of M. Wallace's games are "grail-esque" ("grail-worthy?"). This one is excellent, but will time grant the world a reprint? I kind of doubt it.
Still the best game modeling this period I know of.

item.name: Promised Land: 1250-587 BC
item.comment:
I'm in on the strength of History of the World
Shipping 12/13
Scripted and dull, very uneven multiplayer experience...a lot of downtime.
item.wishlistcomment: A follow up to History of the World...I'm very curious!

item.name: Prosperity
item.comment:
Hoping the hate is just whining.
Well, after playing I understand the sadness. The game works, it plays smoothly and does what it sets out to accomplish. Unfortunately it does so without anyone having fun...there's nothing bad here, just nothing on the level my expectations of a game with Knizia's name on it.
item.wishlistcomment: I am hoping for a game as good as the charm of Blue Moon City

item.name: Prussia 20
item.comment: Stand alone deluxe battle, no mounted map, replaces Jena 20

item.name: P√úNCT
item.comment:
far and away my least favorite GIPF game. the gameflow seems so linear for a game that is 3-D. How wierd. It must be my own limitations, or maybe it is my regular opponent's fault...yeah, that's the ticket it's him, not me!
No, it's me, I suck at this one.

item.name: Pursuit of Glory
item.comment:
overchromed or too fiddly? I guess I'll never know. A bunch of us got excited, bought it and then took a long look...oh my.
