I am sure the game fulfils the needs of a core group that likes this detailed level of play, but my head hurts, PoG is complex enough to meet my needs.
item.conditiontext: cards sleeved

item.name: Quantum
item.comment: A great new game I wanna try at BGG.con, fun and fast to play, this system rewards aggressive gameplay and I like it!
item.wishlistcomment: Dice in Spaaace! I am looking forward to paying this.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: I can't seem to get any enthusiasm going for this...the game is uninspired. The art is semi-amusing and the puns are tedious. As for the game, Deck building with even less control than shuffling...thankfully the game ends very quickly so I can play games like Ascension and A Few Acres of Snow.

item.name: Quartermaster General
item.comment:
Waffling on keeping my pledge...
I bailed on it and realized I'll never get this to the table enough times to rationalize buying it.

item.name: Ra
item.comment:
excellent theme? Pasted on? WHO CARES! This game is awesome! the entirely of the game revolves around knowing when to call RA! You'll have a great time learning that mechanism.
As for me personally, the theme is perfect by means of the flood and disaster tiles. Without those this game would just look nice.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
I just felt like I was playing a solitaire game and the lack of interaction was too much for me to consider replaying.
Replayed this after a few years...the fact that I didn't even pay attention to my opponents tableau during most of the game was very telling. Still dull solitaire.

item.name: Rag'narok
item.comment:
a failed attempt at a mass combat system for Rackham. Regardless the game materials in the box are almost mandatory if you are a fan of the world Aarklash. Histories, alphabets and artwork to make your jaw slacken.
No game here, just a great read.

item.name: Rallyman
item.comment: Dunno, I guess racing games just don't fire my enthusiasm.

item.name: Rampage
item.comment: The more I hear, the more my interest fades, it sounds fun, but more like an activity than a game I'd want to own and play regularly.
item.wishlistcomment: Silly game, with hilarious bits and collapsing buildings.

item.name: Rattenkrieg
item.comment:
a free gift with the honeymoon option...no clue.
It's another Postcard game....ugh.

item.name: Rattus
item.comment:
fun with plague rats. Yes indeed! the variable player powers, the rules regarding role selection, and the limited scope makes this the area control filler game of choice for my crew. Tons of strategy and table talk as we head towards the end game when the plague inevitably "blooms"
"ring around the rosey..."

item.name: Rebound
item.comment: Great kids game that required fresh rubber bands to really enjoy, sort of shuffle board. Necessarily abandoned for lovely games like crokinole

item.name: Red November
item.comment: Oh my, oh my, a game that suck the life out of anything it contacts. A horrid game that answers questions nobody wants asked. I played it only to kill time, it killed time, me and fun.

item.name: Red Poppies: WWI Tactics
item.comment: hoping for a good looking fast playing tactics game...

item.name: Red7
item.comment: Fun but maybe too short

item.name: Reglamentacja: Gra na Kartki
item.comment: Hoping that they include English language rules...
item.wishlistcomment: the next design remembering the challenges of the Polish experience in the era of the planned economy.

item.name: Relic
item.comment:
Children and children at heart will find a lot to enjoy with Relic, and as part of the WH40K brand this has already developed crossover among miniatures gamers the way Lords of Waterdeep pulled in D&D players. Visually the board is heavily thematic and the encounters are all steeped in the lore of WH40K.
Fans of the setting will love this game and its offspring while ignoring comments below.
The busts with interchangeable plugs seem likely the first component to break, and I wonder why the choose to use the plug at all. Overall the components are "stunning" if you like your art beyond overwrought. At a glance the board is nice, but the text is all but unreadable if you aren't pressing your nose against it.
Aesthetics aside the game is an attempt at Talisman envisioned as a taught, tense serious adventure for 4 players...it fails as the gameplay is made fiddly with managing multiple components, inventory slots, trophy types, mission cards, bonus effects, corruption counts...while still retaining the "engine" of roll & move, exact count.
Talisman was a fun romp across a fantastical landscape with the occasional impossible task and was best with huge groups of friends using house rules to speed the gameplay. This revision has lost that simplistic charm of rooting for your best friend to fail and the shared laughter of everyone when the leader sudden transforms into a helpless toad.

item.name: The Republic of Rome
item.comment: the new version is drool-worthy; thank you Valley Games for an excellent treat in 2010!
item.conditiontext: Errata on board corrected with permanent marker, errata on cards corrected with stickers. Cards sleeved.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment: Okay game, but themed games like BSG have it beat. I like this better than Werewolf. They developed a variant based on Arthurian legend...Avalon, like The Resistance seem to be tailing after a themed game...whatever.

item.name: The Resistance: Avalon
item.comment:
A party game that adds mechanics similar to Werewolf to the negotiation/deduction of Resistance. Theme-less gameplay that rests solely on the meta-gaming of one or two Alpha players that eventually makes the gameplay stale and unappealing. Negotiation games and co-op games in general need a higher level of theme and tangible intermediate goals to keep my interest.
They also depend on each player having a clearly defined turn where they act on their motivations and command center stage without being dominated by the meta-game of the game mechanics and the Alpha players.

item.name: Revolution!
item.comment: a fun blind bidding game that just seems to go on too long. to be completely honest i do get frustrated by the potential to get out bid in several actions simultaneously.

item.name: Richard III: The Wars of the Roses
item.comment: a great block wargame, in many ways superior to HotS. I love the combat variables and how each side runs to France when they lose a turn. you're never the usurper for long...

item.name: Rise of Empires
item.comment: Martin Wallace gives the civ game another go...? Yep. And this time it is a winner with distict periods and geography. longer than you'd wish with 5, but great game with 3.

item.name: Risk
item.comment:
I bought the collector's edition from Target for the wood pieces only to find them regrettably sub par quality. They are not quaint, they suck. It is still Risk, so no joy there either.
That B & N Onyx version is nicer, but costly considering the unforgivable typos.

item.name: Risk 2210 A.D.
item.comment: until Nexus Ops, Dust and Risk Legacy, this was the one version of Risk I enjoyed. The aforementioned titles have surpassed 2210AD in everyway to my opinion, but this one still has some charm.

item.name: Risk Legacy
item.comment:
Risk...what can I say...this version is the modern version where turtling can't help, Asia can't be controlled in time to get the benefit, and on top of it the players get power, and alter the board in entertaining and unique ways.
I have no idea if the end product will be cool or hideous, but the first 3 games wizzed by. I think as each player wins at least one the game will settle down and become more of what Risk is traditionally known as, but I'll reserve my opinion 'till I get there.
Fun opening the crazy packets? YES!

item.name: River Dragons
item.comment:
Sad game that looks pretty. Some of the actions are useable only by accident and it is very easy to gang up on one player endlessly.
Pathetic

item.name: Rivets
item.comment: Another fun micro game, not as good as WarpWap or Melee, but still fun.

item.name: The Road to Canterbury
item.comment:
Light and humorous, but unsatisfiying.
The art and component quality are excellent, but the 3-player is a little odd as it seems overly easy capitalize on your opponents plays and kill the pilgrims and then act again.
In my first session I effectively has several turns that were 2 consecutive turns (using last rites tokens) and essentially scooped the 7 deadly sins and 4 spots on the road. Later I did this again, ending the game and engineering the high score on the road. the middle player was squashed. final score. 85-46-85. I won on the tie breaker of the most cubes in the center.
Not horrible, but probably not a good 3-player.

item.name: Road to Enlightenment
item.comment:
Ok, the rule book would have benefited from a significantly more comprehensive proof reading, you're first play will probably be rough, mine sure was.
Regardless there is a playable game here. My preferences would have been for a better dice system than "net BoD, hit on 6's" for conflict resolution. I'm not fond of the "knockout tracks" either as it can be a waste of actions getting bumped off repeatedly.
Because of a hard limit of 5 on conquest, players are obligated to compete in every arena. I will need additional plays, or a better understanding of the luminary cards to navigate the various tracks.
Due to the random draw of most of the cards there is very little national theme, don't look too hard for history here, it's been boiled away by the mechanics.
Overall, I'm very surprised that the publisher is rushing so many projects through Kickstarter as opposed to getting this one cleaned up to establish a strong pedigree...after playing this I'm not looking to support them on anything. It may be that only the designer should caretake this game, but I'd think the publisher would be insisting this be supported robustly. If I understand correctly the rules won't be cleaned up until an expansion is released? The cart is before the horse IMO.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment:
A in-depth adventure with themed worker placement chores. The least enjoyable aspect of the game for me is the fact that it is a co-op. it's just not my preference.
I like that the game is very unforgiving and that losing is more likely than not.
Regardless, I don't see myself playing this often.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment: I just have no skill in this game; therefore I hate it.

item.name: Robot Factory
item.comment:
Still in prototype, but very entertaining game with lots of strategy on moving your robot. Lack of control over the frequency of the parts may affect some players, and occasionally the assembly choices cannot be built, creating a waiting game.
Regardless it is a solid hour of gaming, perfect length.

item.name: Robotanks
item.comment: Bought on a whim, lackluster programming game with crap components...part if the Cheapass phenomena, but little genius here.

item.name: Rock 'Em Sock 'Em Robots
item.comment: eventually your Blue robot's head goes "zzzzeee!" and you've lost...Happy now you Red fucker? Let's see you do that again bastard!

item.name: Rodeo Rummy
item.comment:
Came with Made for Play DVD produced by the Spiel
Comes with a set of dice representing traditional deck of 52 cards...a deck of cards is infinitely more useful and fun...compost.

item.name: Rogue Agent
item.comment:
There is an attraction to the concept of playing a game in "blade runner"-ish world, but I was yet again frustrated with the obtuse nature of this designer's rules as published...see Panic Station version (?) and DDD (revised). I intensely dislike feeling as if I am a post consumerism beta tester.
I am accustomed to crome, exceptions and abstracted rules to invoke theme, but I failed to find a narrative here, the other players and I ran around, did stuff scored points and the game ended...that's about it. No story.
Perhaps this game needs basic scenarios? Not for me to figure out.
The Android scenario was kinda fun as players choose if they would like to be in vs mode via a loyalty reveal mechanic. First one in the deep end gets to fight everybody and destroy the board...not very blade runner after all to me. :(
Regardless the Bomb Disarming Test is great fun for people who love rolling dice...I'm guilty of enjoying that part of the game, and that alone made this worth trying.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment: Dice game version, entertains and doesn't go too long, basically better than RftG in every way

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: Better than it's parent game, at least by virtue of being short. Dice games all dress Yahtzee up and try to say the idea is fresh, but they lie..they like in their cold black hearts. Window dressing aside there is some fun, but not a lot of control. Push you luck everytime. You'll have more fun and the game goes faster.

item.name: Roma
item.comment: From BGG.con, a good 2-player, but I really play with fewer than 3...

item.name: Room 25
item.comment:
Cube as a game, I love it conceptually, as a game it depends on the group dynamic...best with mean people.
I love the dynamics of re-aligning the rooms, especially when winning and losing hangs in the balance, suddenly you are exactly where you don't want to be...and the clock is ticking.
item.wishlistcomment: Sort of a CUBE (the film) as a boardgame? Who knows until you wake up in a strange room with a group of people you've never met...

item.name: Royal Turf
item.comment:
As with all things, games age, this betting game is the fore runner of Colossal Arena...after all is said and done I prefer this version, but the color grades between shades of brown is annoying.
Love the horse names.

item.name: Rumis
item.comment: I have the Rumis version, a great game for spatial puzzle freaks. The Pieces are exquisite and the turntable is inspired to help each player in equal measure.

item.name: Rummy
item.comment: this is the game that taught me it was ok to not enjoy my mother-in-law's company. the rules are always conditional on who is winning and which part of her brain is currently suffering a loss of blood.

item.name: Run for your Life, Candyman!
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
After a recent play (8/3/12) my daughter finally realized that while funny as satire, this is a really poorly executed game. The humor wears off after 30 minutes as the entire table prays for release.

item.name: Rune Age
item.comment: I'm sure that this will see expansions and end up as a hit, however after "A Few Acres of Snow" and "Ascension" I don't need another variation.

item.name: Runebound (First Edition)
item.comment: Truly a game that needed a 2nd edition redux, thankfully FFG was quick to make offers to replace each 1st edition for a nominal fee. A great example of customer service.

item.name: Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment: The game is solid, but like any good game benefits from some tweaking to speed play and promote risk-taking. My group keep coming back to this quite regularly.

item.name: Runewars
item.comment:
saw it last night (1/22/10)...very pretty.
Playing next Sunday.

item.name: The Russian Campaign
item.comment: Classic wargame design, something I should have learned when it was new, but better than never.

item.name: Russian Railroads
item.comment:
Another must-play for BGG.con
Everybody rushed to buy it and play it...then everybody got bored with it. It's not bad, but it faded for me right away.
It is not a train game, that's the problem
item.wishlistcomment: Is it worthy of the hype?

item.name: Saint Petersburg
item.comment: Highly regarded, need to play

item.name: Saint Petersburg (second edition)
item.comment: Need to try it!

item.name: Saints in Armor
item.comment: I want to give the Musket & Pike system a try, the recent GMT sale helped push me into buying this one.

item.name: Samurai
item.comment: a scale-able classic abstract that is very evocative thanks to the tactile scoring pieces. The gameplay is solid and rewards repeat sessions. Next to Ra and T & E, this might be Knizia's best.

item.name: San Francisco Cable Car
item.comment: Fun puzzle route building especially with this stock holding variant

item.name: San Marco
item.comment: Need to play based on recommendations

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: Fun and mean tile laying game with a raise or drop auction and multiplier endgame scoring. Themeless but better with aggressive players.

item.name: Say Bye to the Villains
item.comment:
I was boggled by the rules at first and thought the other players were really caught in AP...it seems like your just supposed to press your luck and negotiate for decent cards from you team and let the chips fall, but the comprehensive analysis of the potential outcomes was too much.
Nothing here to make me try it again.

item.name: Scarab Lords
item.comment: this lays there next to Minotaur lords and goes, eh? (shrugg shoulders)

item.name: Score Four
item.comment: An old family game, fond memories, but no need to play ever again.

item.name: Scrabble: Game Folio Edition
item.comment: i really don't like word games. I'd like to think I have a decent vocabulary, but the people that know the scrabble dictionary are elitist assholes.

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: Drafting and programming your game. This bears repeat plays, but it seems no one brings theirs copies around. Did they lose interest so soon, maybe I am being generous with my rating if this fades so quickly.

item.name: Sekigahara: The Unification of Japan
item.comment:
While I love the setup and sweep of A Most Dangerous Time IMO Sekigahara is more playable with significantly shorter playtime. The card play and combat mechanics are sublime.
The limitations on this point to point map and the muster locations make for a true challenge of resource management.

item.name: Senji
item.comment: After a long time I finally played it. Now I can go back to playing Shogun, A Most Dangerous Time and any number of other feudal Japan civil war games. I found the game to be rather boring with narrow choices and no sense of the politics and betrayal that were hallmarks of this era.

item.name: Sergeants Miniatures Game: Day of Days
item.comment:
2nd edition, very pretty, very expensive, neat concept I'm gonna pay (play, how Freudian) for a while before rating.
Additional item: GM Kit, extends base game with a Storyboard for the cards and lots of useful counters, worth every penny.

item.name: Sergeants Miniatures Game: Red Devils
item.comment: Great KS offering with lots fun extras and additional scenarios. Note this is not an expansion. this is a new base game.
item.wishlistcomment:
Kickstarted
Depends on the success of the kickstarter...

item.name: The Settlers of Catan
item.comment:
A game everyone should try once. Is it a classic? Probably. After the jokes are worn thin, the game endures. Regardless there are plenty of other games I love to play that owe Settlers a royalty check. Or at least a thank you card, most kids leave their folks in a lurch, so don't hold your breath.
Tueber has milked this sucker to the point of irrelevancy and each rendition sells, so I guess it is a bonafide classic. Is it plagiarism to steal from yourself, or just a sign of limited creativity?

item.name: Seven Dragons
item.comment: Color matching abstract with Chaos variables and Elmore art. Worth the one play, not much more...

item.name: Shadow Throne
item.comment: Drafting game with players supporting three factions throughout the entire game hoping to score more influence that the other players, no real theme at all but the game art is great. Very dark comic book type look.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: A fun co-op that everyone should play, just not be surprised when it gets predictable and "task focused" like Arkham...maybe all co-ops fade the same way?

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: The Card Game
item.comment: Take a tedious honey-do errand like Shadows over Camelot, add a memory element. Then never play either again. "Winning"

item.name: Shadows over the Empire
item.comment: Interesting grid-area control game that is frustratingly balanced...so much so that the only way the game ended was by consent. Maybe there is a better strategy to it, but time will tell.

item.name: Shark
item.comment:
Random rolls for placement and gut instinct buying and selling. It's not so much knowing what to buy or when to sell as it is knowing when to go deep on the company that will make it to the top.
Fun and occasionally nasty.

item.name: Shinobi Arts
item.comment: Short quick card game with player conflict as rival teams steal treasure from a palace or each other. Probably best with 4 or 5 for maximum effect and opportunities for betrayal.

item.name: Ships
item.comment: Treefrog subscription 2014

item.name: Shogun
item.comment:
Very subtle with deep strategy options and that groovy tower. I always wish I had one more turn...
Truly one of the must play games for boardgamers.

item.name: Shoot Out
item.comment:
free with my copy of Going Cardboard.
It sat uncomfortably beside the DVD until I gave it away...Victory!

item.name: Showtime Hanoi
item.comment: Part of a Postcard game hangover I got in a trade

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
item.comment: Way better than the original, but unfunny with people that are not three moves ahead when their turn comes up.

item.name: Sigismundus Augustus: Dei gratia rex Poloniae
item.comment:
A perfect theme for me, hope to try at BGG.con. Tried and bought!
A great strategy game with more than passing similarity to Game of Thrones hierarchy system. Replaced the plastic pawns with meeples.
item.wishlistcomment: I am geeking out about this to an irrational level...I may be spending on this first at BGG.con

item.name: Silverton
item.comment: A full on train game with lots to manage...seems like I am flirting with 18XX, but I'm not ready to give in just yet. This is my kinda game.

item.name: Simon
item.comment: Twitch game that I am hopeless at, my wife loves it.

item.name: The Six Million Dollar Man
item.comment: shameless tie-in for a shitty show that shows how low the bar was in the 70's for everything.

item.name: Skittles
item.comment: The fun is in pulling the cord and watching the carnage, the precursor to reality tv

item.name: Small World
item.comment:
Cute art and clever mechanics that eventually fell flat.
I did give up on this before the expansions and for most folks this is a excellent game...but after a while this just wasn't as much fun as my other area control games.
BTW the scaled boards (for the number of players) was nicely done.

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment: Wacky variety of abilities gaming taken to the next level...kinda like Small World race/power meets card chaining as seen in most deck builders. The players get 2 sets of race decks and mix them to form a hybrid power. Silly fun in concept, but text heavy the first few plays. Not awful, but this one is not for me.

item.name: Snatch
item.comment: Entertaining to watch as I played and got crushed by significantly better players. Not a game I would seek out, but not bad. Probably one of the better word games if yo like word games.

item.name: Snowdonia
item.comment:
Nice theme and I like the action selection track.
I am confused by the construction rules...as we learned the game, we were allowed to build station components including rail at the end of the game track while ignoring the connecting track or previous stations? That seemed anti- theme. (I work in mass transit construction, laying rail contiguously is important)
After another play, despite my earlier comment, the game is fun and plays well, the effects and actions allow for multiple strategies. The kicker points from the contracts are where the winner triumphs, so tying each action to the bonus is key...if you take cards you can't score, you're doing it wrong.

item.name: Solitaire
item.comment: computer versions keep us honest with this time waster.

item.name: Some Poles Apart
item.originalname: Some Poles Apart: The Battle of the Westerplatte
item.comment: Postcard games that are no fun, we publish a lot of them!

item.name: Somme 1918
item.comment:
Ordered from Nuts!
Too complex for my preferences, too many counters, too much detail. It does what it intends to do, but it's really long and requires too much active brain power to keep me going.

item.name: Sorry!
item.comment: family level meanness that everyone can enjoy.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment:
Crazy fun that needs a more quiet play space than I typically enjoy.
Innovation in the mixed media genre, done right with another highly amusing manual from the designer of Galaxy Trucker and my fav Dungeon Lords.

item.name: Space Cadets: Away Missions
item.comment: Entertaining escalation into mayhem, strengthens the old axiom "though shalt not split the party." I had fun, then I died, laughing.

item.name: Space Cadets: Dice Duel
item.comment:
A team experience using dice rolling and allocation followed by more dice rolling, with chaotic planning and point blank shooting. I don't know if I would play this regularly or even again.
This will appeal to many social gamers, but I find it slightly tedious. I also dislike that any attack other than point blank is almost doomed to miss.

item.name: Space Empires: 4X
item.comment:
Initially I dislike the bookkeeping. I'd prefer open tech trees. The fleets can be hidden and still give off the FOW...dislike the upgrade rules and the need for endless number counters.
I guess I thought the fleet groups were a single marker with any number of ships hidden, but sorting out each group by tech is counter-intuitive to me.
I still ordered a copy, cause there is enough to like and play semi-regular.
BTW - the open space areas are deadly and hilarious!

item.name: Space Hulk
item.comment:
The first edition got the most support, was very diverse and just plain ugly. Gameplay was a little clunky, and eventually streamlined, but nothing beats a complete set of the first edition.
Except Hybrid...took 15 years.

item.name: Space Hulk (third edition)
item.comment:
A classic given the type of treatment that all good designs deserve. GW may be at odds with a portion of the community, but you cannot deny that the jam-packed this game with the best bits ever seen. Well worth the asking price.
Gameplay

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel ‚Äì The Card Game
item.comment: Not awful, and I would play again, but not at my own choosing. Just not engaging, the miniatures of the parent game and the board map are a staple of the genre. Marines on a conveyor belt/conga line is blah...

item.name: Space Marine
item.comment:
Vastly improved upon in later editions, this started my love affair with GW's strategic games like Epic, Man o' War and Warmaster.
Space Marine is clunky and long as a game.

item.name: Space Sheep!
item.comment:
An abstract with a timer element...and co-op play. Very original game elements, but the theme is horrendous. The complexity ramps up exponentially.
It's well worth trying.

item.name: Sparta
item.comment: Undercooked game that feels like a half step up from checkers.

item.name: Spartacus: A Game of Blood & Treachery
item.comment:
Fun, but too long. I think if you pull out a few cards you'll end up playing the same game, but within 2 hours...it wears its welcome out after a while, too many beat on the leader tactics, and too many easy influence gains combine to make Spartacus too loooong.
The combat is well done and like Lords of Vegas the deal making during the game is very free and devious.

item.name: Spartacus: Crisis in the Roman Republic 80-71 B.C.
item.comment:
Very much rooted in Hannibal RvC with up to three bush fires in distinct theaters (Italy, Asia Minor and Spain). The various enemies all have different unit mixes while the Romans have consistent quality, but are penalized for too many levies at any one time.
Need more plays as this seems to be a significantly longer game than H:RvC with many chained event cards draw from a single deck. My guess is no two full campaigns will play the same. Shorter scenarios assume that history unfolds as documented leaving less to chance and demanding more focused play by each side.

item.name: The Speicherstadt
item.comment:
Clever auction game, possibly the only Feld game that I enjoy. The line jockeying and screwage is wonderful.
Plenty of opportunity for bluffing too.

item.name: Splendor
item.comment: another filler game that feels like Ticket to ride with set collection options. as a twist the cards you purchase create permanent colors for future purchases, so much so that the order that you collect cards can set up a chain of purchases allowing you to play without taking chips for several turns. A winner will be angling towards the bonus tiles ASAP. Not sure that the reserve mechanic is of any use, but I'm sure this will be played often enough to suit my interest.

item.name: Stand at Mortain
item.comment: Crappy postcard nonsense

item.name: Star Munchkin
item.comment: 2nd to the original but worth the occasional romp.

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment: Addictive, but luck driven and prone to ridiculous combos. I've played it in a crazy number of iPad sessions, but I'll not consider playing it in person or multiplayer as I've gotten my fill of this genre from Ascension and Dominion.

item.name: Star Wars Miniatures
item.comment: thankfully I was not seduced by the Dark side, many other young padwans were not so fortunate...

item.name: Star Wars PocketModel TCG
item.comment: There are key moments in life where people have the opportunity to realize they are being used by cynical entities that have a malevolent intent. This is one of those moments. Don't be an Anakin.

item.name: StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment: This taks a popular RTS and turns it into a chore with tons of downtime. Although heavy on theme, it feels like the game is straight-jacketed into tedious design choices that omit the fun. This needed serious pruning at the outset and as such may not interest anyone other than dedicated Starcraft fans.

item.name: Stargrunt II
item.comment: inventive, but too incomplete for most miniature wargamers to get into.

item.name: Starship Troopers
item.comment: An old title I remember fondly; the book was a classic. This game was ok in it's time, regardless it doesn't measure up to more recent wargames.

item.name: Start Player
item.comment:
A comical way of resolving "The Great Question."
At long last I have the means to the beginning with something more than Older, Younger and Owner!
Thanks Ted?

item.name: Steam Noir: Revolution
item.comment: Interesting card plays, but seems like it plays best with 5...the victory conditions are hard to follow initially...need more plays probably.

item.name: Steam: Rails to Riches
item.comment: An excellent game that improves with each play...thankfully so does my skill at playing. Tons of strategy and conflict with only one downside...you have to remain fully engaged or else! Exactly what I want in my game collection.

item.name: Steel Driver
item.comment: Like Tinner's Trail, a fun engaging and "lighter" Wallace game. I love the Pegasus board design. This game deserves a lot more plays than I have given it so far.

item.name: Sticks & Stones
item.comment: great childhood memories of setting up the mammoth hunts. I loved the theme and this was a staple of the microgame era...I wish I still had my copy.

item.name: Stock Car Championship Racing Card Game
item.comment: Take that race game that takes way too long, the pimping that my friends have done is cool regardless

item.name: Storm over Arnhem
item.comment:
Great asymmetrical scenario with a near hopeless defense by the encircled British by an unprepared German counterattack. The attack rules are easy to remember and a fun series of opposed die rolls even out the luck unlike many other games.
The pass, double pass turn ends mechanic leads to unpredictable twists in strategy, followed by swift close combat and the subsequent turn.
Great game.

item.name: La Strada
item.comment: light route building, a easy to teach on-ramp to the world of pickup and deliver games

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: Training wheels for deduction and fog of war, classic from my yourh

item.name: Strike of the Eagle
item.comment: Seeing as how I'll never play Hannibal Barkas, this second game from Robert Zak is a great three-player with tons of replayability

item.name: Stronghold
item.comment:
neat game on scope and challenge, a bit dry trying to imagine cubes as ravaging fantasy creatures and stalwart defenders...artwork and layout are stunning and surpass the weakness of the choice of cubes.
the rulebook as commented by so many people is a mess to plow through, thankfully after a bit the gameplay surpasses the rules, but it is a chore.
Fixed by the valley edition!

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: fun bidding wars, maddening anti-luck dice system I will never say no to a session.

item.name: A Study in Emerald
item.comment:
I'm consistently entertained by Treefrog games, couldn't conceive of passing this one up.
Shipping 12/13
This game is a chaotic beutiful mess of awesome
item.wishlistcomment:
Martin Wallace, Neil Gaiman sir Arthur Conan Doyle and H.P. Lovecraft...ye Gods, but it sounds like a perfect storm!
I wonder what it will be like, but I'll buy it anyway...

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment: Fun and diverting...the gameplay is simple enough, but the text and what you need to remember gives you a lot of options that require a dose of reading and re-reading. After several plays it becomes organic

item.name: Successors: The Battles for Alexander's Empire
item.comment:
side by side with Hannibal and Sword of Rome, easily one of the best CDG ever!
Unfortunately, due to poorly conceived stacking rules the game develops into 2 or 3 "all or nothing" combats with massive armies. The game and the players lose out on deeper strategic play.
item.conditiontext: Great condition, cards sleeved, trade includes C3i #22 (special abilities for Generals)

item.name: Sucking Vacuum
item.comment: ha ha ha. mean spirited fun, but in the end only worth a few plays.

item.name: Sumo Ham Slam
item.comment:
Rated a ten for mindless fun complete with cheering in 4 languages which culminated in our personal favorite...
Hamsterkampfe Hamsterkampfe Hamsterkampfe
(you'd be surprised how difficult is was to find amusing translations)
A simple game that should be played in large groups with spectators. Kids will have a ball with this one. we pooled our money and decide the winner has to hold the game between sessions.
add money and alcohol as necessary.

item.name: Sunrise City
item.comment: Mega chunky tiles are cool, but I just never liked the games scoring mechanic...I traded it for a game I like better, so win for me!

item.name: Super Giant Monster Showdown
item.comment:
A DIY effort that would have fared better with a healthy period of development to trim off the overload in the box. The components were very low quality, but there was the seed of something...possible several something's that followed.
Regardless the designer put a lot of love into it...certainly not an ounce of restraint!
This would have found love in the Kickstarter era

item.name: Super Munchkin
item.comment: I'm in recovery and learning not to buy.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment:
solid and beautiful, at its heart it is hilariously cruel.
the Stronghold edition is excellent. BTW - u want Squid...more chaos more screaming...less whales. HAHAHAHAHA!!!

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment:
Insanely cute and fun drafting game - very charming.
Its only fault is the obscenely low print run...grrr.

item.name: Switch & Signal
item.comment: Well done coop with a tough challenge...maybe too tough, this game needs some work to clear up some rules on the switch mechanics in the cities. Regardless I hope this finds a publisher and this gets access to a wider audience.

item.name: Sword of Rome
item.comment:
Great CDG with loads of player interaction through "card fencing". I especially like to be able to act indirectly by manipulating the minor powers in the game.
Incredible play balance with all of the major powers playing very differently. Worth hunting down.
2nd copy to swap out the old components...this is the best of games.

item.name: Sylla
item.comment: A solid game by the designer of Iliade. The artwork and theme hit a sweet spot for me.

item.name: T.I.M.E Stories
item.comment:
Super production values on a card based "choose-your-adventure" framework. A co-op with a intricate story that is quite literally a one and done session. More to follow each quarter.
Even though this seems like a poor value the gameplay/experience is excellent.

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment: frankly this is a fine game mechanically, but completely devoid of theme, and that makes me lose interest quickly.

item.name: Talisman
item.comment: Cards are black and white, this edition has the folding board, not the puzzle pieces - much nicer (IMO)
item.conditiontext:
main feature of this set - the very nice gate-folded board. missing 1 spell, 1 toad, 1 alignment card and a lot of the counters.
best to trade with the 2nd edition set - if only to get the nice board.

item.name: Talisman
item.comment: the wackier version of Talisman, the expansions are numerous and worth the effort of tracking down, plus there is a very active online player community.
item.conditiontext: Set complete, puzzle piece board (see my first edition trade if you want the nicer gate-folded edition)

item.name: Talisman (third edition)
item.comment: fun, best in a large group.
item.conditiontext: the set is complete, but the box, while intact is showing its age. game components are in excellent shape.

item.name: Tammany Hall
item.comment:
Fascinating 2nd edition version with complete graphics overhaul. Another mean game with cynical manipulation of immigrants and vote fraud...I love it!
Added the Pandasaurus kickstarter component upgrade kit

item.name: TAMSK
item.comment: I have played this games so fast I was out of breath. The strategy varient is fun, but the real challenge is the time-limit version. This one is unlike any game I have ever played. Kris Burm is a genius.

item.name: Tank Battle
item.comment: Nostalgic garage sale pick, not worth the $2

item.name: Tank Command
item.comment: hilarious traps that kill your tanks via a lever mechanism in the board. ridiculous fun.

item.name: Tannh√§user
item.comment: Tannhauser is my most-anticipated game this year, and I am not disappointed! The rules are very well thought out with variable complexity amongst the game modes. Lastly, the components are far and away probably the most attractive production since Hybrid. William Grosselin and FFG really did a proper job with this.

item.name: Tannh√§user Field Ops
item.comment: A game similar to battleground and wings of war with cards as miniatures and terrain. Neat components, but not the most accessible game due to language issues (French only rules)

item.name: Taverna
item.comment: Horrid and comically opaque manual makes this turd a game I was all to happy to abandon mid game. Set collecting, majority and partnership scoring in fantasy taverns.

item.name: Tempus
item.comment: A bit of a mess towards the end, but a mediocre Martin Wallace game is better than thousands of other designs.

item.name: Terra Mystica
item.comment: I'm a lemming following the herd...
item.wishlistcomment: Not a clue, but I want to give it a play or so based solely on the rabid popularity post-Essen.

item.name: Terraforming Mars
item.comment: Neat drafting rules with the best wear mechanism I've seen in a race game. Most fun I've had with this theme ever. Lots of design space to adapt this to other concepts.
item.wishlistcomment: Having played a prototype I'm curious to see what refinements have occurred.

item.name: Test of Fire: Bull Run 1861
item.comment:
Not necessarily C & C light in a scripted scenario; you roll a dice pool to generate commands and draw order/action enhancements from your deck of cards. There are specific area control objectives as well as immediate win conditions. Occasionally you might win by attrition, but the scenario times out when either draw pile is empty.
Well done and fun to play. I like the dice as actions, but only in small doses like this.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment:
Long on my "to play" list I finally played it. The "Time=Initiatve" function works here with depth and purpose that I found lacking in games like Red November and Horus Heresy.
Thebes looks great and plays smooth, although the regularly horrible draws can frustrate players that can't deal with luck components.

item.name: Theseus: The Dark Orbit
item.comment: Buzzzz, very high, wanna play, best as a 2-player
item.wishlistcomment: No clue, but the designer's previous games are excellent

item.name: Thirty Years War: Europe in Agony, 1618-1648
item.comment: A little too much for me to wrap my tired brain around. I'm a big fan of CDG's, but the truth is I may be at saturation on them. I had a mint copy that went unplayed and has since found a good home.

item.name: Three Kingdoms Redux
item.comment: New release that is getting great initial feedback...I'm still trying to resolve my feelings about it

item.name: Three-Dragon Ante
item.comment: psuedo-betting, crappy trick game bogged down by card abilities...way too long and fun rapidly decreases with more than 4 players.

item.name: Three-Dragon Ante: Emperor's Gambit
item.comment: more of what makes this game so forgettable.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment:
Ugh, visually DOA and dull to play. However, like all civ games, it's true fault is length. The game drags for a long time and I can't muster the enthusiasm to play through to the end. Kill me.
The constant shuffling of the tiny discs was annoying, enough so that it still bothers me...

item.name: Thunder Alley
item.comment: Great race game, possibly the best I've played yet. Excellent wear mechanism. There is tons of room in this design for new challenges...this could be tweaked for years to come.

item.name: Thunder at Cassino
item.comment: Part of the storm over series

item.name: Tic-Tac-Toe
item.comment: Once you learn to stalemate, it loses all appeal.

item.name: Tichu
item.comment: Unknown Origin aside this trick-taking game is delightful and makes regular appearances at any table once you try it. It is a staple go-to game when no one can agree what to play. Smartphone scoring apps really help keep the game moving.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
a classic gateway game, always worth playing

item.name: Tiddledy Winks
item.comment:
At the time, I was sure there was a strategy; now I now I was only futzing with tokens for future boardgames.
A stupid dexterity game to trump them all.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: Picked this new edition up on a whim...I didn't even know about it. Are the add-ons worth the purchase? Regardless this is still one one the best games ever!

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: A true hair-pulling brain burner that is equally entertaining and frustrating.

item.name: Tikal II: The Lost Temple
item.comment: Seriously pretty and a neat nod to vanity by the designers including themselves as pawns. Light and fun, not at all what Tikal is. Good family game.

item.name: Time of Crisis
item.comment: I love Sword of Rome, really looking forward to Wray Farrell's next design.
item.wishlistcomment: Roman themes are never to be ignored!

item.name: Timeline: American History
item.comment:
For the Bop
A great new set for timeline
item.wishlistcomment: For Kayleigh

item.name: Timeline: Americana
item.comment:
For the Bop
Like Music and Cinema I prefer the historical variations
item.wishlistcomment: For Kayleigh

item.name: Timeline: Discoveries
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
A great social race to discard with awesome guessing and some use of knowledge
item.wishlistcomment: Kayleigh's

item.name: Timeline: Diversity
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
This adds just what it promises...
item.wishlistcomment: Fun for my family especially my beloved daughter, Kayleigh.

item.name: Timeline: Historical Events
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
Another fine add on to the system
item.wishlistcomment: waiting on an english language version

item.name: Timeline: Inventions
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
fun fact game that plays as quick as you know shit...needs the additional set to stay engaging as memory replaces actual knowledge and good guessing...really nice presentation regardless of lifespan.

item.name: Timeline: Music & Cinema
item.comment:
For Kayleigh
Disappointing...almost entirely given over to post 60's pop culture with a bizarre nod to a few significant moments in the the history of music.
A missed opportunity to cover thousands of years of music and a broader swath of the history of cinema.

item.name: Tinners' Trail
item.comment: Fun and quick playing. Comments that rarely appear together on a Martin Wallace game. A real gem of a game with strong theme and mechanisms. The JKLM version is nice to play on

item.name: Tiny Epic Kingdoms
item.comment: Recently hyped as a micro game, it's really boring and shallow. There is almost no interaction and the winner is determined well before the game ends. Blech!

item.name: Titan
item.comment:
this game and I grew up together when it was a crappy mail order only game, look at how we have grown!
still hate the player elimination...we play with house rules fighting for points and a time limit with titans teleporting after "death". Not as bloody, but better for good friends and repeat playing.

item.name: Titan Legions
item.comment: part of the GW Epic Space Marine game, not a whole lot of fun, but not awful either.

item.name: Titty Grab
item.comment: It's a titty...you grab it a lot...often when it's inappropriate to do so...you get your hand slapped sometimes...the realism is palpable.

item.name: To The Last Man!
item.comment: Pre-ordered from Nuts!

item.name: The Toast of the Town
item.comment: Postcard games are from hell, banish them. ( or give them away)

item.name: Tobago
item.comment: another very pretty game that captures your imagination...and it is great fun to play too. Love the Moai heads and the palm trees.

item.name: Toc Toc Woodman
item.comment:
nutty, and fun, but kinda loses its luster after 5 minutes (my adult voice)
I really liked "Don't Break the Ice" when I was eight.

item.name: Torres
item.comment: AP and smart-ass experienced players made this a dull and irritating series of sessions. not awful, but there are plenty of abstracts i would rather play.
item.conditiontext: cards sleeved; in excellent condition

item.name: Traders of Carthage
item.comment:
Set collection and bidding game. It's all down to timing and knowning when to score or prepare for pirate raiding.
Enjoyable and easy to play with 3 people

item.name: Tragedy Looper
item.comment: A wierd mechanical deduction game that is basically a series of getting it wrong one less time than the loss condition...interesting, but not something I'd play regularly

item.name: Train of Thought
item.comment:
Kayleigh's
Received at BGG.con 2012
Forgettable

item.name: Trains
item.comment:
Route. Building, pick up and deliver, deck building...who wouldn't be curious?
Having played it, I like it well enough to play it if someone has a burning desire, but I'm not seeking it out.
The waste mechanism is the most clever part of the game, other than that it's board element is dull. As a deck builder it's fine, but it pales against Few Acres of Snow and Concordia as wall a Study in Emerald.
item.wishlistcomment: Will I love it...deck and route building? Is this Rolling Freight the deck building game?

item.name: Trains: Rising Sun
item.comment: Adds nothing of interest to Trains

item.name: Transformers 3D Battle Card Game
item.comment:
"it's a cash-waster in disguise!" Decepti-game indeed.
This is an embarrassing game, the designer should be ashamed, but seeing as how he contributed to a heap of mass-market crap, shame is not in his vocabulary.

item.name: Trapping the Ogre
item.comment: Crappy nappy postcard game, given away

item.name: Trenches of Valor
item.comment:
WWI theme is my only attraction to this I fear
The game collapses under the first casualty, with no counter strategy to bad luck ( or better luck)

item.name: Trenchzone
item.comment:
Fascinated by this era...looking forward to the arrival of this games lot.
Tried it and in practice the game falls apart with the most base strategies of min-max. What a shame.

item.name: Tribune: Primus Inter Pares
item.comment: one of the few worker placement games I have interest in. always played with the expansion.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: Master Game ‚Äì Genus Edition
item.comment: roll and move, exact count and trivia...what was the collective unconscious that allowed this turd to flourish?

item.name: Trollhalla
item.comment:
A fun mid-weight family game that will benefit from repeat plays to develop stategy. the random tile draws are part of the fun and causes a lot of jockeying for position.
Sadly this is not a game that attracts repeat play

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment: Fast multiplayer that is easy to learn and get to the table, however I'm not one to suggest it.

item.name: Tumblin-Dice
item.comment: this was fun for all of 3 minutes. I'll stick with Pitch Car when I need to flick...

item.name: TurfMaster
item.comment: Fun light game that has aged well. A good mix of hand management and positioning over three heats. Regardless, it is hard to keep in the game if you dont score in the top 3 each round. A full field leaves several people in the cold after the 1st race.

item.name: Turning Point: Stalingrad
item.comment: Part of the storm over series

item.name: Twilight Imperium
item.comment: this game will never end! I think I am still playing the first session from friggin' 10 years ago...ARGGHH!!!

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment:
Better than all previous editions, but it suffers from one problem, no system to govern enlightened self-interest. Alliance systems like those in Dune and Struggle of Empires allow for players to expand and fight without needing to conquer all before them. This makes TI3 unnecessarily long.
The random draw for the board tiles make the game uneven, somebody gets unfairly hosed.
I'll play occasionally...

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment: it is a challenging game, but not one i care to play often. well done regardless of my personal tastes.
item.conditiontext: 2nd edition

item.name: Twister
item.comment: Dangerous if your over 40, timeless if your under 8

item.name: Twixt
item.comment:
one of the original coffee table games that "sophisticated" people displayed, but could not teach when i was little.
It's not equal to the GIPF series, but I still loved the visual motif.

item.name: TZAAR
item.comment: a great coda for the GIPF project, easily as good as DVONN and YINSH. all of these, except PUNCT are treasured in my collection.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar
item.comment: Crazy gears and crystal skullz...does it make for a good worker placement game? I hope so.

item.name: Ultimate Werewolf: Inquisition
item.comment: I could not get into this, werewolf without the acrimony seems like a time waster to me. Almost impossible to develop a coherent strategy even when you're sure who the werewolf is.

item.name: Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition
item.comment:
Ah, werewolf...so dependent on who is playing, but such potential for memorable evenings as people stretch themselves to act like Machiavelli with a behavioral science degree.
Best served with alcohol

item.name: Unhappy King Charles!
item.comment:
After a lot of discussion with other players, the designer and the developers, not to mention many times at the table; I am a fan.
There is a lot to like in the game and as a simulation of the English Civil War it plays as it is intended; a true challenge for two determined players.
I do feel the game is marred by some omissions and unfortunate presentation choices in the rulebook, map and counter mix. Most of these have proved to be easily solved and with a little DIY I find the game a treat to play.
item.conditiontext: added: new unused map.

item.name: The Union Forever!
item.comment: a pointless postcard scenario...embarrassing.

item.name: UNO
item.comment: it seemed like everyone loved this at first, maybe it was the solid bright colors? it sure as shit wasn't the gameplay.

item.name: Unpublished Prototype
item.comment:
"You didn't see annnything!"
6/26/15 - played a prototype called "Zipang" (Japan) it's a light strategy/wargame that has a lot of chaos at the moment, roll and move, dice combat. Sort of a mix between Risk and Monopoly with card play. Area control on a map of sengoku era Japan

item.name: Up Front
item.comment:
a true wargame classic that should be in every gamers collection, sadly the updated edition is balls deep in a heinous legal snare with no end in sight.
I have no regrets tracking down my AH copy. Don't bother waiting people!

item.name: Urban Sprawl
item.comment:
For me, this is a tedious mixing of Dominant Species (procedures) and Combat Commander (chaos).
Neat mechanically, frustration over chaotic events that seem to happen endlessly. I can do without this one.

item.name: Valley of the Kings
item.comment:
A fun deck builder with lots of synergy among the cards. There are a lot of timing mechanisms that you need to be aware of or else the game will get away from you.
Regardless this one is great because the only way to score points is to "entomb" good cards at a decent pace weakens our options on subsequent turns. Very clever multi-level "trashing" options.

item.name: Vampire Empire
item.comment:
A basic dueling hidden role game, my initial reaction is that it does not pay to attack first, especially for the vampire player, but as soon as you defend with a vampire reveal it and go nuclear.
Additionally, don't bother saving cards, just attack attack attack as soon as your opponent has fewer than 4 cards

item.name: Verr√§ter
item.comment: Predecessor to Meuterer...if these were coming out now, English language versions would have been obvious

item.name: Victory in the Pacific
item.comment:
An excellent low complexity game that has aged well. The historical set up and logistical limitations do not create balance as most people have come to understand it, but the onslaught of the Japanese followed by the irresistible production of the Allies provides both players with equal tension and tough choices as the game progresses.
The day-glo colors of the map are my only negative.

item.name: Vinhos
item.comment: Overwrought worker placement that I played to experience it. It all goes together, but it's not on my list to replay.

item.name: Virgin Queen
item.comment: Although aspects of the game are streamlined, the fun is illusive as the playability of the HRE and France are questionable...England and Spain are clear favorites. Team play against Spain is a must and that just plays into England chances...the Ottoman play on autopilot. :(
item.wishlistcomment: it's getting closer... April 2012

item.name: Viticulture
item.comment: part of the KS collectors edition, upgrade kit

item.name: Vlaanderen 1302
item.comment:
very easy to learn, extremely quick, straight forward gameplay. Our first session was a quick one with no arguements (always a plus). As we become more accustomed to the game I can see subtle planning being a key factor to more intense turns.
Sadly this is not an intense game, not a bad game, just so many better games.

item.name: The Voyages of Marco Polo
item.comment:
I like the artwork (Yunnan), and the game plays fine. Overall it's a mix of mechanisms from other games that kinda of makes me wish I was playing those games. The rich scoring options give lots of room for divergent play.
I have no complaints regarding the game or the rules, but I'm indifferent to playing it again.

item.name: VS System
item.comment: after a few plays it became obvious that i would never be interested in the game, so i cut my losses
item.conditiontext: Hellboy Collector's Edition

item.name: De Vulgari Eloquentia
item.comment: intricate and deep game involving players in a "game of life" expereience with a heck of a lot more actual choices and consequences.

item.name: The Walking Dead Board Game
item.comment: thematic fun for a Walking Dead fan...uninspired roll and move Talisman gameplay for the serious gamer. (is it over yet?)

item.name: Wallachia 20
item.comment: Stand alone deluxe battles, no mounted map

item.name: Wallenstein (second edition)
item.comment:
Probably prefer this to Shogun...but that damn tower is a mixed blessing. Neat idea, but it's stability is why this game will never move up in my desire to play this regularly.
The entire game is very well crafted.

item.name: Walnut Grove
item.comment: Quick, but unengaging. It is well designed and has plenty of replay, but I don't see myself playing again anytime soon

item.name: War
item.comment: its worth it to play to learn basic rules, it's s not something to play past the first few years of a young mind's exploration into gaming.

item.name: War of the Ring (first edition)
item.comment: Ok to play, but I prefer the co-op and the Confrontation before I'd tackle this again.

item.name: War of the Ring (second edition)
item.comment: Maybe I don't need this if I have everything else...who I'm I kidding, thus is a great game and both versions are great.

item.name: War of the Worlds
item.comment:
Interested in trying this small wargame. Really attractive small game, great fun.
51 hex counters 51 round counters
item.wishlistcomment: A fun famous theme fit for a wargame

item.name: Warhammer
item.comment: I played, and then I stopped playing. That way I always win.

item.name: Warhammer 40,000
item.comment: played through 3rd edition and learned all about rules lawyering and "codex creep". Once I realized that the fiction was better than the game, I took up reading.

item.name: Warhammer 40,000 (fourth edition)
item.comment: the game was a staple for many years and then I just sort of burned out on it. In '06 I gave away all of my books and sold my collection to anyone willing to aid in my recovery...

item.name: Warhammer 40,000 Collectible Card Game
item.comment:
I probably never took this seriously and surely missed some cool game play.
On second thoughts, I was right. This is uninspired and dull. Gave it away...

item.name: Warhammer Epic 40,000
item.comment: I played this right up until Armageddon was in playtest. I wish GW knew how to market their good designs...

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion
item.comment: It was okay, but never really catches my attention. The attack/defense mechanics make sense, but are so dependent on decent regular draws...a few too many enhancement draws and no troops and your soon overwhelmed. No real strategy sat the deck building.

item.name: Warmaster
item.comment:
what Warhammer should have been, excellent system.
BTW, no one played this gem for long.

item.name: Warmaster
item.comment: a relatively weak wargame scenario tied to the original version of Horus Heresy. this is the last moments of the Emperor in his hunt for Horus within a star ship. Fun to be the Emperor or the other Primarchs, but only worth playing once. Free with the issue of White Dwarf 161.

item.name: WarpWar
item.comment: one of my first loves as a youngling, spent hours making sketches of my designs. Based on cost and number of plays this was by far one of the best games of its generation.

item.name: Warriors & Traders
item.comment:
Civ and conquest game where combat is an option? Yes! Quick and easy? Yes! Lovely design? Yes! It also has a top notch "How To..." PP presentation on a CD in the box to supplement the rulebook.
My first play was fun; I like the "draft" turn cycle (similar to Rise of Empires, but more open ended) and the dice-less combat is simple and efficent. The tech tree is easy to adopt too once you're used to the game terms.
A great new discovery at the start of 2012!

item.name: Warriors of God
item.comment: delightfully easy to learn and a great wargame. The system of leaders aging and the ebb and flow of a sustained conflict is sublime and occassionally frustrating...like real life.

item.name: Wars of the Roses: Lancaster vs. York
item.comment: Fun chaotic game that I would gladly play, it's no war game by any metric, but I like the look of the game and the treachery of devious self-interest this game demands.

item.name: Washington's War
item.comment: The opening salvo in the CDG wargame gets a new edition. Good game, but not equal to Hannibal. Really dislike the attrition rules.

item.name: Waste Knights
item.comment: Seemed similar to Runebound with a Mad Max setting. I like that the opponents always choose your encounters and the timing of them.

item.name: Waterloo
item.comment: an abstract way of doing a wargame...odd at first and then very enjoyable...once you get past any expectation of a simulation this game is worth many plays.

item.name: Waterworks
item.comment: i loved this game as a kid, wrenches, pipe fittings copper upgrades....it's a wonder I didn't end up a plumber, I still remember it fondly.

item.name: Way Out West
item.comment: great fun, high on theme and promise of what Wallace brings to the game table

item.name: We the People
item.comment: It is the opening salvo in CDG and IMO does not age well. The Battlecard gameplay is very dull. This system eventually yielded Hannibal RvC, Sword of Rome and POG and for that it deserves respect, but I have no need to play it again or own it.

item.name: Weapons of Mass Destruction
item.comment: added to Nuclear War. More wacky fun
item.conditiontext:
generous trade offer:
Nuclear War Nuclear Proliferation Nuclear Escalation Bonus Pack #1 Complete set of Booster cards Weapons of Mass Destruction
minor box shelf wear; components in excellent shape

item.name: The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow
item.comment:
Everybody has or will eventually play this; but party games are not a success for everyone...I am one of the apostates that finds no joy in this group game. Adding the crazy characters just confuses the players and makes the game unnecessarily complex.
I'm content to see others enjoy this while I pay anything else.

item.name: When Darkness Comes: The Awakening
item.comment:
this is a gem of a game hidden by the worst rulebook I ever managed to struggle through. So bad I re-wrote it and sent it to Twilight.
In the final review of this game, it is a dicefest game that my crew won't tolerate.

item.name: Wildcatters
item.comment: I was initially drawn to the theme, but with games like Crude, Planet Steam and Giganten, I find this pales in comparison.
item.wishlistcomment: A must play at BGG.con

item.name: Wing Leader: Victories 1940-1942
item.comment: Given to a home that will give this more attention than I will. Too detailed for my tastes. Lovely regardless.

item.name: Wings of War: Burning Drachens
item.comment: The rules are refined and include tons of optional play. With this edition the games improves quite a bit. More fun than ever.

item.name: Wings of War: Famous Aces
item.comment: fast and furious gameplay, very exciting. the game rewards strategy and gutsy moves.

item.name: Wings of War: Watch Your Back!
item.comment: adds extra planes, but same rules as the first set. great fast fun.

item.name: Wir sind das Volk!
item.comment: Great 2-player of struggle between east and west, it's not Twilight struggle and it's not trying to be. Play it.

item.name: Witch of Salem
item.comment:
A refreshing battle against the Great Old Ones, all the perils and stress of the Lovecraft Mythos compacted into a 1-hr rocket-ride to damnation.
For me this is what makes a good co-op, a little good fortune, a lot of tough decisions and no re-rolls.

item.name: Witchcraft
item.comment: a fun abstract with a lot of strategic depth, best if played with a few house rules to remove random asymetrical character tokens and random draws (IMO)
item.conditiontext: this copy comes with the bonus characters.

item.name: The Witcher Adventure Game
item.comment:
The Witcher is a wonderful Anti-Hero, I hope the game does the license justice. I never played the video game, but I read the book series and saw the TV/Movie. the movie was ok, but the books are excellent.
The game is horribly dull.
item.wishlistcomment: interest built on the excellent collections of novels.

item.name: The Witches: A Discworld Game
item.comment: Ordered a pair, one for me, one for Kayleigh
item.wishlistcomment: 2nd in the Discworld series

item.name: Wiz-War (eighth edition)
item.comment: Lots of screwage and blissfully short. The new production is well done, but the gameplay shows its age. Personally I want a game with more win conditions, the mix of King of the Hill and Capture and Control gets dull quickly as somebody gets shanked and then a sniper benefits from the work of others.

item.name: Wizard
item.comment: good addition to melee, but not as much fun...the effects of casting powerful spells are debilitating on the Wizards leaving them vulnerable.

item.name: Wizard Kings
item.comment: The fun of double blind block games returns with a vengeance. this is one of my fog of war faves (after HotS)!

item.name: The World Cup Game
item.comment: A game that predates Blood Bowl: Team Manager, but is very similar. I can see the appeal to World Cup fans and I enjoyed the time spent with friends. I would play it, but you'll never catch me suggesting it.

item.name: World War II: Barbarossa 1941
item.comment:
icon driven, hidden orders and simultaneous reactions. not to mention great minis and plenty of scenarios.
a great deal of stuff in the base kit, and each expansion pack is $4.00.
Just getting into the game, but it plays quick, clean and rewards clever tactics. very surprised and much better than my "knee-jerk" first impressions.
The dry erase rubs off too easily.

item.name: WWE Superstar Showdown
item.comment: Great fun with R-P-S. Add in the chance for random card draws as tie breakers (a la "War") as well as tailored character decks that mimick WWE heroes & villains, and you are set for a quick set of rounds center stage. Having an affinity for wrestling goes a long way to amping up the fun, but this is a game anyone can happily play.

item.name: Xactika
item.comment: if you own it, just chuck it in the trash, you'll feel justified.

item.name: Xanad√∫
item.comment:
A crazy number of icons, drab art and boring card plays makes for no fun...add into this that you must constantly examine half the cards upside down and I get a headache.
This is a recipe filling game I can do without.

item.name: Xia: Legends of a Drift System
item.comment: Looking forward to play this...it's good if you play with 2 other people only

item.name: XXXenophile
item.comment:
ugh...it's compost now.
I love the Godzilla role-play image that was the cover of the 1st comic, but XXXenophile was a purerile book with weak humor and mediorce art throughout.
This game was not a step up.

item.name: Yahtzee
item.comment: Where all modern dice pool games come from, classic

item.name: Yedo
item.comment:
Mean worker placement game that feels a tad too long...I'm also not too fond of some of the action cards that steal stuff. The event cards are cool and harsh at the same time.
Overall I like it, for now...

item.name: YINSH
item.comment: challenging game that I have not won at, but I love each session.

item.name: Yunnan
item.comment:
Pretty, but not getting a post-Essen bump...might be less than it seems.
Happy to report that my initial enthusiasm was rewarded with a tight, aggressive game involving pay-to-play bidding on several improvements, shoving actions based on influence and a game cop that is nominally attacking the bully. You very quickly deduce shrewd discrete actions that punish your opponents and lure the authority to look elsewhere...
The board design is lovely and the language independent turn sequence is managed on the board requiring no referring to an icon glossary.
I'm happy that the designer choose worker placement with no player boards, it's so satisfying to take direct actions and in turn face my opponent's wrath.
Excellent.
item.wishlistcomment: In my mind this us better than the initial buzz

item.name: Zen Garden
item.comment: Sounds light, but oddly intriguing...a boring abstract I bought and then gave as a gift as soon as I realized it not for me.
item.wishlistcomment: Sounds light but intriguing

item.name: Z√àRTZ
item.comment:
outstanding member of the GIPF family. This is the abstract for everyone.
I upped this from 9 to 10! This is my personal favorite of the series. Get GIPF set 2 to extend the play value of ZERTZ to infinity!

item.name: ZhanGuo
item.comment: Chinese theme, please the emperor, contribute to his kingdom, oppress the peasants. Yummy

item.name: Zombicide
item.comment:
Very amusing and truly a cooperative game, you need to go over the rules carefully and accept that it seems easy at the beginning because you missed something important. The various characters all have something they are "best" at, you need to use that skill constantly.
If you're a killing machine, survival is a secondary consideration.
The miniatures are much less impressive than they appeared on the kickstarter campaign, but I'd be lying if I didn't acknowledge they are above and beyond what most game pawns look like.
This may be the penultimate zombie game, but I'll happily play your copy.
Mall of Horror is better in my opinion, because the behavior and stress it elicits is less fun and more human.
Regardless, I cannot deny the appeal of wielding a chainsaw, wading into a zone full of the undead and giving them last rites.

item.name: Zombies!!!
item.comment:
good beer swilling f-ck you gameplay.
Thank you Todd and Kerry!

item.name: Zombies!!! 4: The End...
item.comment:
a well conceived game, both as an expansion and a standalone game.
better than the first, as a game at least.

item.name: ÂãïÁâ©Â§úÊÄïÊÄï
item.comment: silly version of Werewolf with locations that players "run" to by tapping the table. This is where the game breaks down as it's very easy to notice if someone is not drumming the table, betraying their role. Ruins the fun.
